author: {'steamid': '76561198019327608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1709162532}
review:
The 39 Steps: A Buchanian Adventure Unfolds, (Mostly) Hands-Off

Embark on a thrilling journey through John Buchan's classic adventure novel, The 39 Steps, in this interactive experience. However, be prepared for a unique adaptation, as this game leans more towards a visual novel format than a traditional adventure game.

The narrative unfolds through beautifully rendered still images and voice acting, faithfully capturing the suspense and intrigue of the original story. Players primarily take the role of Richard Hannay, a man thrust into a world of espionage and murder, by making choices that progress the narrative.

While the immersion is generally strong, the experience is occasionally disrupted by minigames. These simplistic puzzles and action sequences, while attempting to add variety, feel out of place and detract from the game's core strength: storytelling.

If you're looking for an interactive experience brimming with suspense and classic adventure storytelling, The 39 Steps delivers. However, those seeking a more traditional adventure game with extensive player agency might find themselves wanting.

I have played this on Linux using proton, and with cups of tea as another reviewer put it, although the scottish undertones have made me yearn for some uisge.

Now go read the book, then watch the multiple film and TV adaptations of this amazing story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077992324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1707088350}
review:
This is not a game, but rather a visual story with limited moments for interaction. It is (or was once upon a time) a well-known story that Alfred Hitchcock based a movie on, and later was also turned into a stage play. Allegedly it also served as inspiration for Ian Fleming when authoring the James Bond novels.
Personally I found the story (which I had not read before) to be mildly interesting but with too many unbelievable bits to really draw me in. It might be better when reading the original novel. But with this "game" implementation, I got bored halfway through and struggled to finish it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047089807', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1655400588}
review:
The 39 Steps is a very interesting adventure novel by Scottish writer John Buchan, which was published just under a hundred years ago. During all this time, the novel has gone through many film adaptations, the most famous of which is Alfred Hitchcock's version, released in 1935. Only in his film, the legendary director, most likely in a fit of inspiration, went far from the original source and made a very tense thriller out of a spy story. The developers from The Story Mechanics decided to make a game based on the book. They decided not to follow in Hitchcock's footsteps and embody the entire plot of the book in their game, including even quotes.
But did they succeed? It is very difficult to answer this question. First of all, it is worth noting that this is both a game and a book at the same time and your task is to lazily sip coffee from a mug and follow the plot. In The 39 Steps, you have no influence on the subsequent plot. You don't even have the right to choose. You simply follow the written plot clearly, reading the written dialogues. But if the developers decided to do just that, then perhaps the plot in the game should be amazing?
It looks very interesting that all the characters, including the main character, are presented in the game in the form of translucent silhouettes. Probably, the developers decided not to distract the players from the plot, hoping that their imagination itself would draw the proper images. But in reality, these yellowish perfumes are damn distracting from the perception of the plot and look a little strange.

But the main problem with The 39 Steps is that the developers loaded their work too much with unnecessary details. Against their background, the whole essence is lost. But it‚Äôs very cool that classic literature is moving into such a non-standard format. We can only hope that this is not the last book to become a video game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971078704', 'num_games_owned': 1106, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1695097822}
review:
The 39 Steps isn't a game at all. I knew that it was a "visual novel", but I had a different conception of what that meant. It is important to realize that there is no gameplay (besides occasionally deciding the order of what to click or matching pre-defined actions), no choices or branching storylines, or anything like that. Instead, this is just a story told with a combination of reading, watching (mostly still images), and listening (where it is more like a radio play than an audio book).

With that being said: I quite enjoyed it, and was pleasantly surprised by the high production values. The voice acting is good, and there are a surprisingly large amount of images made just for this.

As a general rule I wouldn't prefer this kind of static storytelling to normal books, audio books, or movies, but I did enjoy my time with this and thought it was interesting and kind of a cool way to experience a story. As long as you understand what The 39 Steps actually is (and what it isn't) and are interested in giving it a try I would recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996859750', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 392, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1692311706}
review: Nice interactive audio-visual adaptation of a novel. Be warned this has no puzzles nor branching paths or any kind of challenge. But if you want to enjoy a relaxed, fully narrative experience, this can be your thing. I didn't like the pre-WW1 British setting at first, and almost abandoned it. But I gave it the chance and it ended hooking me up, and enjoyed it. If you like crime and mystery, maybe you'll like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040407532', 'num_games_owned': 1403, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1692209606}
review:
Every other review says it but I'll reiterate: this is a visual novel with extremely minimal gameplay mechanics.

I have neither read nor watched The 39 Steps so I cannot comment on how faithful an adaptation it is. What I will say is that it offers a compelling story, supported by excellent voice-acting, art and music. I didn't feel like the interactive elements added a great deal but I'm not generally someone who will seek out VNs, so your experience may well differ. 89p at full price is exceptional value.

I have two minor criticisms. First, there isn't complete checkpointing, so if interrupted you may need to go through short passages (2-3 minutes at most) again. Second, I encountered some minor startup bugs where I got the main screen music but a black screen on launch. These were fixed by a simple restart of the program, but it's slightly jarring at least.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198824302304', 'num_games_owned': 887, 'num_reviews': 551, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1689524110}
review:
After playing this game I saw the alfred hitchcock movie based off the same book as well, I'd say this game is at least as good. Although it's ofcourse a very different medium and experience. And the hitchcock movie has mostly a very different plo even.

I appreciate the attempts they make to make this more than a visual novel, with lots of voice acting, zooming in pictures, and short point and click sequences. The story is also told pretty well and gives you the abbility to skip some trivial information from time to time if you feel bored.

On the downside however, the interface and controls are sort of terrible, space brings up the menu, but doesn't close it, and esc doesn't do anything unless you're in the main manu, than itt closes the game without warning. Turning your mouse to go to the nex dialogue is also something that is a lot more fun in theory, luckily clicking is also an option.

For this price, if you're ino thrillers, you'll probably like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023452776', 'num_games_owned': 1570, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1681613343}
review:
The 39 Steps √© um jogo de fic√ß√£o interativa emocionante baseado no romance de mesmo nome de John Buchan. O jogo o transporta de volta para o Londres de 1914, onde voc√™ joga como Richard Hannay, um homem que foi acusado falsamente de um assassinato que n√£o cometeu. Conforme voc√™ navega pela hist√≥ria, precisar√° usar sua ast√∫cia e intelig√™ncia para limpar seu nome e descobrir um plano sinistro.

Um dos recursos mais marcantes de The 39 Steps s√£o os incr√≠veis cen√°rios pintados √† m√£o que fornecem um pano de fundo impressionante para a hist√≥ria. A aten√ß√£o aos detalhes na arte √© verdadeiramente impressionante e realmente o imerge no mundo de Londres do in√≠cio do s√©culo XX.

Outro aspecto do jogo que se destaca √© a dublagem. Os personagens s√£o trazidos √† vida por algumas performances fant√°sticas, o que realmente acrescenta √† experi√™ncia geral de imers√£o. O design de som tamb√©m √© excelente, com uma trilha sonora melanc√≥lica e atmosf√©rica que ajuda a definir o tom do jogo.

Em termos de jogabilidade, The 39 Steps √© classificado como um jogo de fic√ß√£o interativa, o que significa que √© essencialmente como ler um livro, mas com certa interatividade. 

Em geral, se voc√™ √© f√£ de fic√ß√£o interativa ou thrillers, The 39 Steps definitivamente vale a pena conferir. O jogo √© lindamente criado, com visuais deslumbrantes, √≥timas dublagens e uma hist√≥ria cativante que o manter√° na ponta da cadeira. A sensa√ß√£o de jogar o jogo √© semelhante √† de ler um livro de maneira descontra√≠da, mas com a vantagem adicional de poder participar ativamente da hist√≥ria. √â uma sensa√ß√£o estranha, mas incrivelmente satisfat√≥ria e que os f√£s do g√™nero v√£o adorar.

review:
"The 39 Steps" ist ein faszinierendes Spiel, das auf einer der bekanntesten Spionagegeschichten der Welt basiert. Das Spiel bietet eine spannende und herausfordernde Erfahrung, die mich von Anfang bis Ende gefesselt hat.

Die Grafiken und der Soundtrack des Spiels sind einfach hervorragend. Die Entwickler haben es geschafft, eine fesselnde Atmosph√§re zu schaffen, die mich in die Welt des Spiels hineingezogen hat. Die Charaktere sind gut gestaltet und die Umgebungen sind detailreich und abwechslungsreich.

Die Geschichte des Spiels ist auch sehr gut gemacht. Es ist eine Mischung aus Action, Abenteuer und Krimi, die mich immer wieder √ºberrascht hat. Ich fand es toll, wie das Spiel es geschafft hat, mich immer wieder vor neue Herausforderungen zu stellen, w√§hrend ich versuchte, das R√§tsel zu l√∂sen.

Ein weiterer Pluspunkt des Spiels ist die Steuerung. Es ist sehr intuitiv und einfach zu bedienen, so dass ich mich immer auf das Spiel konzentrieren konnte, ohne mich um die Steuerung k√ºmmern zu m√ºssen.

Insgesamt bin ich sehr zufrieden mit "The 39 Steps". Es ist ein gro√üartiges Spiel, das ich jedem empfehlen w√ºrde, der nach einer spannenden und herausfordernden Erfahrung sucht.

Meh,should have just been a left-click style visual novel,I mean it's a story,it's not a game,or fun as a game to me. Wasn't interested enough in the story to keep trudging through. Really hate that clockwise-counterclockwise mouse stuff,just make it a click. T___T

author: {'steamid': '76561198009573440', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1672087453}
review:
It's interesting to review a visual novel without reviewing the fiction itself, which is Buchan's The 39 Steps, a classic pre-WWI spy thriller. If you like VNs, espionage, and mysteries, this quick work (it'll take a few hours to go through) is worth your time.

Anyone unfamiliar with The 39 Steps should note there is an antisemitic character early on, but the story doesn't follow in that vein.

"Interactive Fiction" isn't quite what I'd call this adaptation--there are no branching paths, no text parser, no commands or dialogue options, no puzzles to solve in-game. You can reason out the mysteries alongside Hannay, the protagonist, but there's little other gameplay for you as a player. You can choose to view all the items in "interactive scenes" or skip them, and you can do some tracing during a few sequences, and that is all.

The novel adaptation is well-presented, and the voice acting of dialogue overall good--solid job on dialects and the German. The illustrations and music are also pleasant and set the mood and tone very well in each scene.

Regrettably and predictably, at almost 10 years old, the software has some trouble on modern systems. Nothing game-breaking, but you may need to force-quit and restart the app a couple times, and it tends to minimize unpredictably on left-clicking. Fortunately the game has pretty generous checkpointing, you can insert "bookmarks," and generally successfully pick up where you left off any time with the Continue option which seems to autosave the last screen you were on.

It's a shame The Story Mechanics didn't seem to release anything else. I would've liked to have seen them refine their vision for adapting older fiction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035192487', 'num_games_owned': 4065, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1453654586}
review:
Achievement Completion 20/20
Enjoyment 9/10

Read this years ago back in college; it's actually a pretty decent suspense "spy" novel, though quiet aside from the rare moments of voice dialogue. I actually wish it was fully narrated or read-aloud like an audiobook, but I think the environmental sounds and effects more than make up for setting the mood. It's a quick breeze-through that is perfect for finishing in a day, compared to most visual novels that seek days of reading and re-plays. There is no replay value here, just a solid one-and-done experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042620952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1366, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1665356449}
review:
[h1] Genre [/h1] Ein Interaktives Story Driven Adventure

[h1] Story [/h1] Das Spiel basiert auf einen Roman. Wir spielen einen Mann namens "Richard Hannay" und leben an sich ein recht Normales, langweiliges Leben in England. Eines Tages steht ein Mann vor unserer T√ºr der unbedingt mit uns sprechen m√∂chte, wir bitten ihn herein und er erz√§hlt uns seine Geschichte, das er verfolgt wird und nun Angst um sein Leben hat. Er bleibt in unserem Haus/Wohnung f√ºr ein paar Tage und wir finden ihn pl√∂tzlich mit einem Messer erstochen vor. Angst das wir beschuldigt werden, schnappen wir uns sein Tagebuch und begeben uns auf die Flucht durch das ganze Land

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] Es ist wie gesagt eine Interaktive Geschichte (Spionage Thriller). Wir lesen und h√∂ren den Sprechern zu. Die Story ist in 19 Kapitel/Level aufgeteilt. Zwischendurch m√ºssen wir etwas anklicken oder mit der Maus einige Zeichen nachmachen. Gespielt wird nur mit der Maus und zwar brauchen wir lediglich die Linke Maustaste. Es ist kein Visual Novel aber es hat schon √Ñhnlichkeiten. Voice Acting is v√∂llig ok und auch die Musik ist passend

[h1] Achievements [/h1] Es gibt insgesamt 20 Erfolge. Alle sind Story basierend also muss man nur das Spiel komplett beenden

[h1] Pro/Contra [/h1]
+ Gute Story
+ Gute Musik
+ G√ºnstig
+ Voice Acting ist v√∂llig OK
+ Spannend
+ Achievements
+ Sammelkarten

[h1] Fazit [/h1] Ein gut gelungener Spionage Thriller. Es ist spannend und die Erz√§hl weise fand ich gut gemacht. Wer gerne Story Driven Adventures mag, kann sich das hier ruhig mal anschauen, mir hat es sehr gut gefallen

author: {'steamid': '76561198027047516', 'num_games_owned': 2303, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1663967002}
review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements in games (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
The 39 Steps is the digital adaptation of a novel, a thriller written by John Buchan that also has a movie adaptation. Personally I never heard of this book and played most of the game without knowing it, but I decided to watch the intro video and this is explained there. The story is captivating and the text is presented in short paragraphs, most likely abridged from the original and it‚Äôs never too much to read. Besides being an interactive book, divided in several short chapters, it also offers other materials that enrich the experience and set the historical period, like newspapers, maps, photos from archives and also a few short cartoon animations for certain side stories.

The paintings used as backgrounds and illustrations for the story are very well made, with pleasant colors and contrast, and depict both indoor and outdoor scenes realistically and meticulously. Sometimes they are complemented with small animations and effects over them, like light rays or smoke.

The voice acting is also top notch in all characters and you can easily notice the dialect differences between characters, and I could barely understand some accents like the Scottish one. The historical rigour is also noticeable in some words that are used and are not very common today, most are related to the closing used by people at the time.

When it comes to gameplay, this is mostly an interactive book, but does have a few short parts of finding objects like in a HOG and some parts where you have to draw figures with the mouse, similar to Detroit Become Human. To move the text you can make circles with your mouse, but using the left and right arrows is faster and easier.

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 20 Achievements, all story related.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 3,5 hours, calmly reading and checking everything.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Very Easy, the interaction is minimal and you can‚Äôt really do anything wrong.
[b]Achievements‚Äô Difficulty:[/b] Very Easy, just finishing all scenes should be enough but to be sure, find all objects in the parts where you have to.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
The 39 Steps is an interactive book, with a bit of hidden object and mouse drawing parts, that was a very pleasant surprise and a great experience, especially if you like reading and thriller novels.

review:
Great visual novel, with some interactive elements.  I have this game in my library for years,  started a few times, did not get into it,  lost focus and uninstalled.  This time I was driven to give this novel a  serious chance.   And I am glad I did!   Atmosphere is really nice. The variation between the interesting story in visuals, audio,  readable materials and story text,  is very pleasing. The visual presentation and audio, really added to the story.   A good story too.  Recommended for a relaxing evening of reading/watching/ listening.  Thumbs up!

NOTE: THIS IS A NOVEL, NOT A GAME!  APART FROM A FEW INTERACTIONS, THERE IS 0 GAME PLAY!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059255363', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1659817099}
review:
This review is coming from someone who has never played a visual novel before. 

I have no idea whether its good compared to other visual novels. Personally i found the lack of actual gameplay very boring. As a non native English speaker I came across alot of instances where i had no idea what certain words meant. Which made it quite confusing. I found the story itself quite confusing as well. 

All in all i dont recommend this game to the people who arent into these type of games, nor the people who expect actual gameplay. I also found that the amount of decisions very lacking, its a very linear story. You might wonder why i played this, and its because i challenged myself to play every single game in my steam library.

review:
I got to say that if I found playing the game very refreshing experience - when starting i didn't really know what to expect, and I was certainly not expecting a 1914 based thriller. I haven't played one of those since .....The Last Express?
Story is well written and voice acting is top notch.
I hated the fact that game would shut down every time I tried to alt+tab, but eventually i got used to it, and stopped interrupting the chapters which are not very long, so... 

Even if you are not visual novels fan (like myself), but you like a decent story, give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129771193', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1644465737}
review:
This game is based on the novel written in 1915. As such, it's somewhat dated by modern standards - it's a fairly slow moving story that doesn't really get interesting until about half way through. The second half is pretty interesting though. I suggest anyone considering this game see if you think you would enjoy the novel first.

Pros:
- Very well voice acted
- The art is pretty good

Cons:
- Whenever you open something (door, window, book, etc) you have to do these mouse movements. Straight lines, circles, etc - nothing even remotely difficult. This seems to serve no purpose beyond making sure you're still awake
- Instead of clicking to advance the dialogue, you move the mouse in a circle
- The first half of the story is pretty boring - as previously mentioned, this isn't a criticism of the game, but comes from the age of the novel it's based on
- I have some Scottish family but there was still quite a bit of dialogue, slang, etc, I didn't understand. Having some sort of reference would have helped, both for slang and dated terms

Verdict: 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198080425368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1639936455}
review:
[h1]The 39 Steps NON √® una Visual Novel[/h1]

Ne ho provata una di VN tempo fa, si chiamava The Letter. L'esperienza mi ha lasciato sconvolto. 
TONNELLATE di testo ridicolo con un environment ripetitivo e characters dalle tinte cringe. Le scelte e i bivi di narrazione non erano all'altezza di quello che mi aspettavo dato che parliamo di prodotti totalmente narrativi.
Un vero e proprio click simulator che sembrava senza fine.

Avevo paura per The 39 Steps, ma gli ho dato una possibilit√† come la dar√≤ ad altre VN in futuro.
I ragazzi di The Story Mechanics ci introducono ad un genere nuovo denominato "Digital Adaptation" ossia l'adattamento interattivo di un'opera esterna, in questo caso il libro "I 39 scalini" di John Buchan.
L'opera segue di filo la storia come viene raccontata nel testo (pertanto nelle DA non ci sono scelte o finali alternativi), con una divisione in 16 brevi episodi. Tranquilli, non avrete da leggere tanto testo quanto ne porta il libro, non ce n'√® bisogno dato che le immagini e l'audio fanno il grosso del lavoro.

C'√® molta variet√† di location e le arts non sono male, sono ben esplorate durante la narrazione e il "lettore" potr√† interagire con vari oggetti di scena. Le gesture del mouse interagiscono quando servono azioni meccaniche come l'apertura di una porta o... l'accensione di una miccia ;)
Ho adorato come gli sviluppatori siano riusciti a mantenere lo stato di tranquillit√† e tensione che ogni scena suscitava, sia con l'audio che utilizzando accorgimenti grafici e di interfaccia.

Purtroppo credo che The 39 Steps sia unico nel suo genere. Non ho trovato altri adattamenti dello stesso tipo e se l'esperimento √® fallito...peccato. D'altronde √® un incastro troppo stretto tra l'avventura grafica e la Visual Novel, che forse non ha permesso di inquadrarlo bene nel panorama in cui voleva crescere. In poche parole non √® stato capito, soprattutto essendo uscito in un periodo dove la Visual Experience era agli albori.

The Story Mechanics ci dimostra ancora una volta come gli Indie hanno le palle di esplorare terre sempre nuove dell'intrattenimento.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037502679', 'num_games_owned': 844, 'num_reviews': 247, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1638916712}
review:
An interesting way to tell a story and very enjoyable. It is pretty much a visual novel with some minor interactions at times.
Only thing I didn't like was the move your mouse clockwise/anti-clockwise to move forward in dialogues. Felt like sometimes it didn't respond to it for ages. Should just have used right/left arrow keys instead or let people choose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002468544', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1638940250}
review: As a longtime lover of literature, I enjoyed this game very much. As others have noted, it is a slow game. But  the deliberate pacing is faithful to stories of the time. The game really invokes the atmosphere, manners, and language of that era.  And the game art is wonderful and adds drama to the game. The only negative comment I have about the game is that the small "puzzles" that you need to do to open doors are unnecessary and distracting. But that's easy to overlook. If you're looking for a relaxing, interesting game, pick this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025815697', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1672724019}
review:
The art is beautiful. The voice acting is great. The sound design and music is top-notch.

But, man, is it sslllloooww.

Fades are slow, transitions are slow. And while I don't mind it being a visual novel instead of a game, if that was the goal, then that's what it should have stuck with. The weird pattern drawing microgame they dropped in to open/unlock a door is out of place, off-putting, and weird. I think I'll just read the book.

Recommended with the caveat you're not playing this so much as viewing it, and you should be prepared for a slow-paced experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119121162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1638743586}
review: It's an espionage thriller adapted to a game. Not much in the way of puzzles or action or non-linear story-telling, but it's worth playing for the atmosphere and the authentic writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561199020934809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1638036970}
review:
A mediocre adaptation of a great book. 
I suspect this may be the developers' first PC game, because the controls are utter dog shit clearly more suited to consoles or touch devices. Honestly, who's ever had a visual novel tell them to rotate their mouse clockwise to turn to the next page, and counterclockwise to turn to the previous page, only to then find out that half the time the latter is impossible anyway?! I ask you... 
Are there then no redeeming qualities? The artwork and music are pleasing to the eyes and ears, respectively, but nothing amazing. The best thing about the game is the copious amount of high resolution flavor texts, in the form of letters, books and especially newspapers.
Is that enough for me to recommend buying the game during a sale? Had there been support for controllers, for which the mechanics were clearly designed, then it might have been. As it stands, however, just go read the book, which is out of copyright and freely available online.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026276775', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1132, 'last_played': 1637705624}
review:
This is not a game. Nevertheless, I enjoyed watching the story untill the last chapter.
It's basically an interactive film adaptation of a classic man-on-the-run story. And a very nice one too! 
I loved the graphics, the music, the voice-ating and even the slow pace of the story. It takes you right back in time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025200596', 'num_games_owned': 1251, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1633210243}
review: I'm surprised how much I like The 39 Steps. It is more an interactive story than a game. I play a chapter and go do something else. I let my mind think about the chapter before I play the next one. It gives me time to imagine the time and place of the story. I imagine what will happen next and let my self be surprised when the story goes in a different direction. It limits how many chapters I can do in a day, but I'm enjoying the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053371429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1630860247}
review: This is more visual novel than interactive game, but it's an excellent and interesting visual novel, based on an actual novel by John Buchan. Sale price can get under one euro and it has easy achievements and cards.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066541492', 'num_games_owned': 2247, 'num_reviews': 271, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1461880358}
review:
The 39 Steps is sort of an interactive visual novel adapted from John Buchan's 1915 classic adventure thriller. It's been adapted many times across several mediums, including film, radio, theater, and television. As far as I know, this is the only video game version of it so far. 

The story follows Richard Hannay, an average British man who has returned from abroad just prior to World War One. At home, he meets his new American neighbor who turns out to be a spy working against a mysterious German cabal planning to destabilize Europe. Wacky hijinks ensue and Hannay goes on the run across the UK to stop the evildoers. The plot feels like a forerunner for Ian Fleming's works with James Bond and spy fiction in general. 

I think the best thing to ask yourself before getting this game is "do I like visual novels?" There aren't really any choices and the game leads down the same path. There are some light gameplay elements, but nothing overly major. You can look at old newspapers and sometimes have to move your mouse in certain directions to interact with objects. The real draw is the writing, which is faithfully transposed from the original novel with voice acting. This is still a 100+ year old novel, though, so the writing won't be for everyone. I personally enjoyed it, but I can understand why some people couldn't get into it.

This used to be a lot more expensive, but now it's fairly cheap. It usually goes on sale for $1 to $2.50, and I think it's worth giving it a shot at that price.

review:
This was a good one. A 70/100 effort.

[b]The good[/b]

Tells a rollicking, classic story
Faithful to the source material
Well drawn and presented, excellent production values
Good and fitting music
Great voice acting
One of those rare games you want to stick at

[b]The bad[/b]

Minimal replay value
Doesn't scale well to larger monitors
If you lack the patience for visual novels, this won't change your mind

review: The story was nice not gonna lie for what I suppose is a sumarised plot of the book, but what kept me curious and overall engaged with the game were the beautiful sceneries, the music and the ocasional simple minigames. For me this was not a game that I could play from start to finish in a day or two, but it was one that needed breaks because it becomes a bit boring after 3-4 events. Overall, I do recommend this game for people who have the patience for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198216537667', 'num_games_owned': 1993, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1626061970}
review:
I quite enjoyed this experience.

It is an experience, not a game.
It is not a "Visual Novel" as some keep calling it.
It is an Interactive Novel.
There is a difference.
Based on a real boo, this is a blending of an e-book, partially voiced, partially read, partially interacted with to advance the story.

The art is gorgeous. The voice acting is amazingly good. The music and audio is good, appropriate, fitting the scenes and the atmosphere the art places you in.
The story feels a bit cut-off, a greatly shortened version of the actual book it is based on, but including every word and detail from the book would cause this experience to be far too long for enjoyment.
Very little "gameplay", clicking on things to interact, swiping in shapes to indicate actions.
Linear, no real "replay value", unless you enjoyed the story and want to go through it again to see the gorgeous artwork and hear the wonderful voice acting.  The historical photos give a look at what things looked like back then, and the mock-up newspapers and handwritten notes are quite good, with an option to read the "important" parts in bold plain text.

Each event can be played one at a time, making this good for short sessions. 100% achievements are gained by simply going through all events, and watching the credits at the end, to get to the final bit of story after them. 
5.0 hours for a full playthrough. 

Worth the price if you like reading, enjoy immersion into the story with the lovely artwork and audio elements, and enjoy historical fiction. It was a nice experience for me, and i will have to go to the library to see if I can find the actual book to read it again.

Not for everyone, though. If you are looking for Choices Matter, or High Action, this will not be for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041183916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1625507679}
review:
[Quote] [b]Per altre recensioni segui üëç il nostro [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34310167]Curatore in lingua inglese[/url] e il [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40165899]Curatore in lingua italiana[/url].[/b] [/Quote]

Dall'omonimo libro di John Buchan che ha ispirato il James Bond di Ian Flaming e numerosi adattamenti cinematografici, arriva questa trasposizione videoludica che ci catapulta in un intrigante spy-thriller ambientato nell'Inghilterra del 1914.
Tra inseguimenti e colpi di scena, siamo chiamati a scoprire il significato dietro le parole " The 39 steps" (tra l'altro lo stesso numero di capitoli in cui √® suddiviso il gioco) per arrivare alla conclusione e risolvere il mistero.
Inutile dilungarsi troppo sulla trama, perch√© si parla di un classico dei thriller, quindi basta solo dire che √® coinvolgente, vi terr√† col fiato sospeso dall'inizio alla fine e probabilmente, proprio per questi motivi, qualcuno lo completer√† in una sola sessione.

Trattandosi di un gioco che si presenta come visual-novel di un libro, non √® molto articolato nel gameplay, giusto qualche enigma ed interazioni disseminati in uno svolgimento del tutto lineare (quindi non aspettatevi scelte e conseguenze).
La grafica √® composta da disegni statici che ben ricreano l'atmosfera della storia raccontata e dell'epoca in cui si svolgono i fatti; la musica potrebbe risultare un po' ridondante per qualcuno, ma per me √® assolutamente gradevole e si sposa bene con le varie situazioni narrate.

Credo sia un gioco che, pi√π che intrattenere, si prefigga lo scopo di rendere lettore anche chi non si √® mai avvicinato alla lettura, specie di classici, e a mio parere ci riesce molto bene.
Ho molto apprezzato la possibilit√† che offre nelle impostazioni di scegliere "Testo originale" comprensivo di termini dialettali come opzione di lettura, perch√© ho sempre preferito i testi integrali agli adattamenti.

Consigliato a tutti, meglio se conoscitori della lingua inglese poich√© √® prevista solo la traduzione in gaelico ed anche in lingua inglese alcuni termini sono di stampo arcaico.

10/10! This incredible interactive visual novel takes you through a twisting narrative where things get more and more desperate! The soundscapes for each scene are incredibly effective at getting me to inhabit whatever space our hero finds himself. Incredible storytelling with gripping moments of terror and twists, but also with relaxing vistas with gorgeous art. 
I REALLY felt like I was in England during that period of the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198202503919', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1618847435}
review:
I have bought this game a couple of years ago and  played only now, I had different expectations for this, so the following things surprised me:

1. This is not a detective game.
2. This is not even a point-and-click game.
3. You don't have any freedom and you just follow the plot.
4. There are very few "game"-ish moments and 90% of the game is just reading / listening.


But don't get me wrong, this game is still really good. I have not watched the movie and have not read a book, so I knew nothing about the plot. The story is interesting and all of the actions starts in the second chapter and it keeps you intrigued until the very end. The voice acting is nice, the art is really beautiful and I spent more time looking at landscapes than I planned. 

"39 steps" is a great visual novel, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who wants to be immersed in thriller-action-James-Bond story with very atmospheric and detailed artwork.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080878825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1618635661}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083592990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1463734323}
review:
[i]‚ÄúIt was a soft breathless June morning, with a promise of sultriness later, but it was delicious enough swinging through the little towns with their freshly watered streets, and past the summer gardens of the Thames valley...‚Äù [/i]

This [i]interactive story[i], based on the book by John Buchan, manages perfectly to capture that feeling!

Audio - both music and voice acting - and visuals are harmonious, the artwork outstanding. 
As for the story, it's an authentic adaption of the book, so no complaints there. It's gripping and immersive.
The price is very fair for what you get.

I'd recommend The 39 Steps to anyone who has an interest in thrillers.
Maybe you are interested in the story, but do not want to sit through a movie or read a book? 
While this is an interactive novel, it's a lot more refreshing than just reading a normal book.
And yes, even people who already know what The 39 Steps about can find enjoyment in it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013134208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1614991928}
review:
Kein Adventure Game, aber eine gut gemachte Visual Novel mit hervorragender Vertonung. Nichts f√ºr Ungeduldige, da die Story (so fern man sie nicht von John Buchan's Buch aus dem Jahr 1915 oder den Verfilmungen her kennt) gerade am Anfang sehr langsam in Fahrt kommt und das Erz√§hltempo doch recht langsam ist. Au√üerdem sollte man schon einige Englisch-Kenntnisse haben, da es keine Deutsche Vertonung oder Untertitel gibt. Die Darstellung der wenigen Videos fand ich sehr gut gew√§hlt, da sie gut in das Handlungsjahr 1914 passt (einen Ton-Film gab es damals schlicht noch nicht). ;-) Der Anspruch ist im Prinzip kaum oder gar nicht vorhanden, da es nur einige wenige Point+Click-Aufgaben, einige "Wisch-Gesten" und keinerlei selbst zu l√∂sende R√§tsel gibt. Es ist halt kein wirkliches Game. Man kommt so oder so zum Ende / zur Aufl√∂sung. Dennoch fand ich mich ca. 5 Stunden gut und gem√ºtlich unterhalten. Man h√§tte auch nebenbei noch locker ein bis zwei Kannen Tee genie√üen k√∂nnen. ;-)
Meine Wertung: 75/100.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025000100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1613931868}
review:
A very well done visual novel based on the book of the same name. Some highlights:
- Outstanding landscapes and locations that it's a pleasure to look at
- Excellent voice acting, it was nice to hear well done Scottish accents
- Plenty of great sound effects to improve immersion
- Very accessible, thanks to voice acting, subtitles, bookmarks and the possibility to read images as text
- It is a faithful adaptation of the novel
- Judicious use of mouse gestures for some actions

Perhaps some transitions could have been a little bit faster, but in general this is an excellent labour of love that allows to experience The Thirty-Nine Steps through a new medium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121192049', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1609819462}
review:
This is an entertaining way to experience John Buchan's 1915 novel The 39 Steps (there is also a 1935 Hitchcock film and several other adaptations). It is enjoyable, but be aware that it is primarily a visual novel with lots of narration and voice acting (although there are still blocks of text that are not voiced). There are some stylized animated segments, but most of the graphics are stills (usually with a digitally painted style) that fade, pan, and zoom in sequence. 

The player has a lot of control over the the pace of the story sequences, but there is no fast forward button or rewind button for some sequences. There are limited elements of a hidden object type game that is usually easy, but on occasion the player might click on the object that triggers a change in scene before everything was fully explored. It is easy to get all of the achievements though. 

I did find a few voice acted sequences in the middle chapters that had voice sequences initiating twice, making a slightly annoying echo effect, in what must have been an unintentional bug (at least on my install). I cannot fault the presentation as a whole - the voice acting is superb, the visuals / music / sound create an aura of suspense, and the fluff text of newspapers draw the reader into a sense of belonging to the period. Overall good, atmospheric, exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083473909', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1609305643}
review:
The 39 Steps √© uma adapta√ß√£o digital do romance de John Buchan (1875 - 1940), livro de mesmo nome que inclusive comprei devido ao jogo.

O jogo ent√£o ele √© um point & click imersivo, aonde voc√™ interage com itens, cen√°rio etc... v√£o ter textos e pequenas cutscenes com di√°logos contando a hist√≥ria no decorrer do game. author: {'steamid': '76561198097994433', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1612528978}
review: It's extremely basic, but it gives a good visual experience to the original story. Even though it's just point and click, it's still very fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013866056', 'num_games_owned': 2627, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1450214283}
review: An interactive novel adapted from the book The 39 Steps. There are no choices or alternate paths to be found here, no romantic interests, and no stats to raise, what The 39 Steps does is an excellent job telling the story of the book. The painted art style and music used are enjoyable to look at and listen to and fit very well with the story being told. The voice acting is excellent and the music and sound effects over the voiceless text perfectly set the tone of the story. You are able to interact by clicking on things around the environment, either to advance to story or to find things like newspaper clippings, photographs, or items that can be read or looked at in order to learn more about the world at the time when the story was was taking place or about the backstory of characters. The game also has you perform actions like making a circular motion with the mouse when you perform certain actions like turning a doorknob. The 39 Steps is a well done adaptation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110152608', 'num_games_owned': 889, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1606565989}
review:
The 39 Steps

My estimated review score before playing: 5/10
My final review score: 6/10. Basic, average game.
Buy/Pass?: Buy. Only buy in a super deep buy or bundle.

Pros:
+ This is the actual inspiration behind the creation of James Bond.
+ The voice acting was great. As was the song during the credits.
+ I enjoyed collecting the extra pieces of content.
	

Cons:
- Mac users beware! The achievements only work on Windows.
- Be sure to not press Esc twice in a row. It exits the game.
- Sometimes text during cartoons sped by faster than I could read.
- As a HUGE animal person I hated part about the horse.
- You may enjoy using the mouse to draw inputs, but I didn't.
- No replay value.

Warnings:
! Nothing to note.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079805996', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1608459536}
review:
This is the most faithful adaption of The 39 Steps book... to a fault. If you've read the book and enjoyed it, then this game-ish adaption's visual presentation is its only selling point to give this adaption a chance. If you've seen the movie and/or play adaption, then this adaption's narration is its saving grace for wanting to proceed further in this game.

However, with that said, this is a relatively short game clocking at an average of watching the movie adaption twice for a 100% completion. Trochievement-wise, they are more straight-forward than the in-game collectables, which give this adaption of The 39 Steps the more interactive feel compared to any other adaption.

Overall, even if you haven't experienced The 39 Steps by reading the original novel, watched any of the adaption and/or just want a bit more interactive/immersive experience with this particular story, then spending $5 or less is worth it. Also, even if you save that $5 and use it to buy a copy of the book, still check out this adaption's soundtrack regardless since you should [still] listen to it as you read your copy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198683591285', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1625415199}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050441866', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3091, 'last_played': 1606000270}
review:
Not so much a game, more interactive fiction, which on the face of it sounds dull, but for those that love atmospheric period tales of intrepidity and legerdemain with a good side helping of British derring do, you'll love it.

Standard gamers that live for all out FPS gung ho counterstrike or black ops type things won't likely find it appealing, as it's all atmosphere, narrative, good ambient sound effects, voice acting, 1914 Belle Epoque period detail and a little nostalgia for a bygone age.

If you like adventure stories give it a spin, it's cheap enough and true to John Buchan's "Richard Hanny" novels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077090852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1605401833}
review:
This is such a wonderful elevation of a literary work.  Gripping, engaging and beautifully done.

As someone who loves to read but has aphantasia and cannot picture things as I read them, this was a great experience for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025522562', 'num_games_owned': 1499, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1604865679}
review: This is a well made adaptation of a novel made into a "game" of sorts. You mostly spend your time with this game listening and reading about the story that unfolds and you progress by klicking and on occation moving your mouse in simple patterns. This is not a game for everyone, but for the ones that likes a story I will recommend you spend a few hours with this. It's a pretty decent novel, the visualizations are good, the audio fits the piece and the voiceovers are really good with a lot, I mean a lot, of dialect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198341439836', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 353, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1604145571}

author: {'steamid': '76561197962492129', 'num_games_owned': 848, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1604263106}
review:
This is a beautiful visual novel. The sound and art are incredible, as the story plays out before you. There is very little interaction during the game, so you're mostly clicking through the scenes & reading the dialogue. 

Not sure if there would be a lot of replay value, but completely worth a read/play-through once. You could burn through the game very quickly, but if you're reading it like a bedtime story you'll probably spend around 4-5 hours completing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198402214760', 'num_games_owned': 1455, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1601309911}
review:
When playing The 39 Steps, you might catch yourself thinking, ‚Äúmeh, I‚Äôve seen this all before.‚Äù  But just bear in mind that this is one of, if not, THE first.  Some would argue that the one man vs everyone on the run genre from Mission Impossible, the Bournes, North by Northwest, The Fugitive, Minority Report, etc was hatched from Buchan‚Äôs novel that this game is based on.
Now I use game in a very loose way here.  This is a visual novel you can drink a cup of tea in one hand while you advance the scenes with your other.  There are a few quite silly QTEs but mostly you will just be taking in the beautiful artwork and following the voiced conversations and reading the occasional newspaper or scrap of paper.  The story is the real reason we are here and the game is just a vehicle for that.

[h1] PROS [/h1]

[list]+  authentic.  Whatever faults you find with this game, you cannot fault them for authenticity.  This game is a direct lift from the book unlike the multiple movies that have been shot.  Also the voice acting is incredibly real.  Real enough to the point that you will need subtitles if you are not from Scotland.  I‚Äôm from Scotland and there were even points where I had to tilt my ear to the speaker and pay full attention.[/list]

[list]+  artwork.  There are so many beautiful backdrops in the game.  Nothing in the game is animated to move but the artists have really put it all into gorgeous natural vistas.  I took a fair amount of screenshots.[/list]

[list]+  voice acting.  As noted above the voices are very authentic but not only that, they are well acted too.  Hannay our main protagonist is a suave citizen with a knack for espionage and assumes the identities of a bunch of different walks of life in his efforts to evade his pursuers.  Other characters in the game are equally voiced and this made the game way more enjoyable than me just clicking through walls of text.[/list]

[h1] CONS [/h1]

[list]-  convenience.  Now, I did say before that The 39 Steps was the genesis of this genre but at the same time I need to call out the plot for its hugely convenient moments where things just seem to fall out of the sky for the main character.  In a bit of a pickle?  Don‚Äôt worry, here is a case of dynamite.  Need a quick alibi?  Don‚Äôt worry you just made a new friend who will cover for you.  There are plenty more examples of this but it would be anachronistic of me to fault the story.  I imagine this was totally fine back in the day.[/list]

[list]-  oh, about those QTEs.  They are not even Quick‚Ä¶.or even Timed.  That makes them just, I don‚Äôt know, E‚Äôs.  I do not need a QTE to make a cup of coffee or to get dressed.  It‚Äôs almost like the devs said, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no game here.  It‚Äôs just a story you click through.  Shall we just add a dozen random QTEs?‚Äù[/list]

[h1] THE CONCLUSION [/h1]

[list]The 39 Steps is a great story to mouse over while you unwind at the end of the day and don‚Äôt want to think or move too much.  It is an easy 100% cheevo too if that‚Äôs your thing.  If you liked this game then Simon Meek went on to form his own studio The Secret Experiment after this and they released a game called Beckett, which I already own but haven‚Äôt played yet.  So I suppose I know what I will be trying next.[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198101328220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1599930235}
review: I really enjoyed this. The graphical style, illustration, sound design and voice acting are all great. It probably appeals more to the bit of me that loves great radio adaptations than to the bit that loves adventure games (though having a mix of both helps). The visual novel style allows for a much more complete adaptation than film or radio usually allows for. The story is broken up into (sometimes uneven) chapters - I don't know how much this follows the original chapters of the book, but nicely breaks things down into digestible chunks. There are some interactive elements, but they are limited to clicking certain areas, or giving mouse strokes in various directions. These add interest, but the main joy is in a good story well told.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108383681', 'num_games_owned': 874, 'num_reviews': 1050, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1599393699}
review: What a great story, what a great adaptation, what a great voice acting. I know it was made with financial support, but I am even more glad it was made with support. Because otherwise this game would be another poorly made visual novel. Really good job for making this game, for recreating The 39 Steps for new audiences!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987977449', 'num_games_owned': 800, 'num_reviews': 261, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1599383848}
review: The ultimate in linear storytelling. Excellent artwork brings the colour in a great masterpiece by John Buchan to life for a modern audience less inclined to the turning of pages. A story of 2 solo operators much like the modern James Bond of today in the moving pictures. Totally re-readable , or in this case re-playable thanks to the way the artwork is brought to life with a moving soundtrack and artfully placed sound effects along with intermittent narration. Be transported back to 1914, and a very different Britain, although maybe not that different, you be the judge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139791883', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1598392597}
review:
This "game" [strike]is[/strike] was the first on my list, which I received from Shado' almost exactly 5 years ago. It's a visual novel, but in the very strict sense - you are literally watching/clicking through a story. There's no puzzle or adventure aspect, it's just John Buchan's 1915 thriller adapted to be run through on a computer.

My first experience was the game launching in 1080p, black barred, on my 1440p monitor. "No matter," I thought, "I'll just change it once this intro finishes." The intro finishes, and I'm presented with a save/load screen, and no settings menu. At all. The only setting for this game is the language, although that does at least include disabling subtitles, V/O, and [i]Gaelic[/i]. A Google search later and it turns out the only way to fix the resolution is by editing the registry. So far, some... interesting technical decisions, but it did at least run at 3440x1440, 144fps with no issues.

The "gameplay" has some interesting mechanics. It borrows some point and click elements, but they're obviously very linear and mostly unnecessary; they're almost there to check you're still paying attention. It features some abstract use of the mouse to progress through the story, you have to make clockwise or anti-clockwise motions to advance/backtrack through the story text appearing on screen, or complete some quicktime-esque sections by drawing shapes to perform actions (such as opening a door). My favourite element of the game is where one character will be telling a story to another, which is condensed into a comedic animated silent film format. Some elements of the gameplay felt very unnecessary, where sections would be presented as topics on the screen, on which you'd have to click and then read through.

The story itself is set in May-June 1914, and focuses on our protagonist Richard Hannay, a bored, middle-class former mining engineer who gets caught up in the affairs of an American anti-semite. Most of the story feels very forced and [i]too[/i] unbelievable (I mean I get that it's a thriller but come on), and the fact that it's all based around a Jewish conspiracy is very much a [i]yikes[/i] - anti-semitism is only mentioned once, as one of the "biases" in Scudder's work, though, looking into this further, apparently the book does more to dismiss/criticise this element of the story, but this adaptation seems to omit that... The story progresses at reasonable pace until the end, where everything feels like it wraps up rather quickly and abruptly. I'm not sure if it's the digital adaptation or the book, but I'm not going to read it to find out.

While most of the story is presented through text on the screen, conversations are voice acted. The voice acting is good overall, though it mostly sits on the extremes of the represented accents - from very posh Imperial British, to harsh Scots, to Cockney London, guv'nor. Scotland is home for most of the story, though despite this most of the characters we meet are still very posh, received pronunciation types.

Generic spooky thriller music accompanies most of the story, though it is broken up by a sick techno breakdown in the credits - I couldn't stop laughing when the glitch noises and bass kicked in. It's a VIP remix of the main theme by Si Begg, available on their Soundcloud.

Overall, I'd say this is reasonably enjoyable if you're into the interactive storytelling thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049823783', 'num_games_owned': 1712, 'num_reviews': 1265, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1595532250}
review:
Aventura Point & Click poco fuera de lo normal, casi pareciendose mas a una pelicula interactiva de imagenes (con nula intervencion) que a otra cosa.

La propuesta en si no estas mal, de hecho las imagenes, la ambientacion, sonidos, voces y algunos recursos visuales estan MUY buenos (como el de las siluetas o el uso del Mouse para manipular "objetos" con movimientos).

Pero el lore es muy confuso, se hace un ABUSO de las pantallas de texto y no se termina de entender nada.

Otro gran problema: solo esta En ingles.

Honestamente no le pondria ni pulgar arriba, ni pulgar abajo, no termine de entender el juego despues de casi 4 horas de jugarlo y llegar hasta el final, pienso que si hubieran puesto mas empe√±o en pulir el lore, seria un juego bastante decente.

5.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198031038796', 'num_games_owned': 1045, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1596821855}
review:
As others already said, this is not game, remember that. If you are up for a good story, although at least for me with a little bit underwhelming ending, to go though in 4.5 hrs, go for it.
The good: 
- the story
- voice acting
- art style, obviously subjective
- nice and clean UI, designed with KISS principles 
- bookmarks mechanics
- short chapters

The average:
- ending
- music is lacking

The bad:
- virtually no options to customize the look & feel (but this is rather understandable taking into account design choices)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972566358', 'num_games_owned': 1866, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1596077807}
review: I'd recommend this for people if they know what they are getting into. It's not a game, it's a visual and audio experience of a novel. It has less choice than what you would expect from a visual novel, it's basically just a click to proceed 'game.' The espionage in the start of WWI story is pretty decent and the artwork is interesting. The acting is pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198214084811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1595988625}
review: The 39 Steps is a visual novel that is based on an actual novel. I have not read the book so I do not know how well the adaption translates. The controls are basic but explained well enough. The developers tried to add as much interaction as they could. Even so, this is mostly a click and receive more text game. The story itself is quite fascinating. The delivery both visually and audibly is superb. Everything seems as though it was hand-painted. The voices were instrumental in making this story come to life. There were even a few old-timey mini-movies. They were my favorite part. If you want to relax for an afternoon with a mix of a visual novel and audiobook grab your favorite bottle of wine (or a few ;) and taking part in a conspiracy just before the first world war.

review: ÂéüËëó‰π¶ËØÑ‰ª∑‰πüÂ∞±ÈÇ£Ê†∑ÔºåÂü∫‰∫é‰π¶Âàõ‰ΩúÁöÑÊ∏∏ÊàèË°®Áé∞‰πüÊòØÂêåÊ†∑Âπ≥Âπ≥Êó†Â•áÔºåËÄå‰∏îÂá†‰πéÊ≤°Êúâ‰∫íÂä®Âü∫Êú¨Âè™ËÉΩÁÆóÊòØ‰∏™ÊúâÂõæÊúâÂ£∞ËØªÁâ©„ÄÇÈü≥‰πêÂíåÁæéÊúØÁ°ÆÂÆûÁî®ÂøÉËøòÂéü‰∫ÜÔºå‰∏çËøáÊÉ≥Ëé∑ÂæóÁ¥ßÂº†Âà∫ÊøÄÁöÑ‰ΩìÈ™åÂª∫ËÆÆË∑®ËøáÊ∏∏ÊàèÂíå‰π¶Áõ¥Êé•Áúã1935Âπ¥ÁâàÊú¨ÁîµÂΩ±ÂêßÔºåÈáåËæπScudder‰∏ç‰ªÖÊÄßËΩ¨‰∫ÜËøòÊòØ‰∏™ËÇ§ÁôΩË≤åÁæéÂ§ßÈïøËÖøÁöÑÂ§ßÁæéÂ•≥ÔºåÂ∏åÂå∫ÊüØÂÖãÊâßÂØºÂì¶ÔºåÂ∏åÂå∫ÊüØÂÖãÁúüÁöÑÂæàÊáÇÊÄé‰πàÊîπÁºñÂéüËëó„ÄÇThe original book review is mediocre, and the game based on the book's creation is also unremarkable. It lacks almost any interaction and can only be considered as a multimedia e-book with pictures and sounds.The music and art are indeed carefully crafted, but if you want to experience the tension and excitement, it is recommended to skip the game and book altogether and watch the 1935 film adaptation. In the movie, Scudder not only undergoes a gender transformation but is also a fair-skinned and beautiful woman with long legs. Directed by Hitchcock, who really knows how to adapt the original work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029204948', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1595426216}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968652342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1404766530}
review:
I've read the original book, and I found this "game" to be a superior way of experiencing The 39 Steps. It brings more life to the story with excellent pictures and narration, and a little bit of interactivity.

Even if you don't care for the the time period or for old British novels, it still makes for an interesting thriller with lots of twists and turns.

This is a visual novel and not a game. A lot of the people leaving bad reviews seem to be expecting it to be something more than that, but it isn't supposed to be. It's just a story with some bells and whistles. If that's want you want, you'll like The 39 Steps.

review:
I survived nine minutes.

Staring at text I've already read hoping at some point the game/story would recognize I was making circle motions with my mouse and unblur the next bit got frustrating very quickly.  Right click out to menu, seems to be no options where maybe I can change "hey dummy make a circle" to "press a button for brevity"...

I'm out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002637002', 'num_games_owned': 775, 'num_reviews': 353, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1590623476}
review:
Keeping in mind this is not so much of a game, as a visual novel or digital audio/visual book version of a classic novel, it is worth "playing" through to experience that well told story. It's visually well put together, though most of the interactive parts feels quite gimicky; The gameplay is this title's weakest point.

The voice acting is mostly quite good, as is the art and overall visuals used.

There's quite a bit of text you'll need to read throughout the story though. It feels a bit of an odd choice as I imagine the main appeal of this sort of title would be as an alternative to reading the book - similar to listening to an audio book instead. This title feels more like it can't decide on one thing, however, and instead of going fully with the audio visual storytelling, it keeps a lot of the story in text form. And while I didn't particularly mind, I also enjoy reading books in general.

Some bugs are also present, such as dialogue playing twice on top of each other with a delay. However, it's not much, and shouldn't spoil too much of the experience.

All in all though, it's a good way to experience a good story. Just don't expect any proper gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021432764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1590219089}
review:
THIS IS NOT A GAME! Don't mistake it as such.

As the product description says, this is a visual novel. You do a lot of clicking and reading and very, very little "playing". Even that's not really the right word because your interaction with the story is clicking on glowing sections of pictures to get more information.

The only real "game"-iness of this is that you sometimes have to use your mouse to "draw" on the screen in a pattern the novel gives you (draw an up arrow, down arrow, left arrow, clockwise circle, etc).

Having said all that simply by way of warning, the novel is presented very well and in-depth. The story is excellent, the art is phenomenal, and the "extras" are also pretty neat to see. I don't know that I'd pay $5 for it, but if you can get it on sale, do it. If you like the novel the story is based on, full price probably isn't a bad deal either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102898526', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1590256377}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064392148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1587663707}
review:
"Thirty-nine steps... high-tide 10.17 pm"

The 39 steps is a "digital adaptation" of the book from John Buchan, telling the story of Richard Hannay who found himself brought amid a conspiracy during the spring of 1914. 
The story is cleverly told through some of the book excerpts, beautifully hand-drawn illustrations, newspaper articles, letters, character/objects cards, short silent movies and simple mini-games. And the least we can say, is that this is remarkably well done here.
The dev has a great knack for visually telling a story as could be also seen in his other game Beckett. 
I am now curious of what would be his next work about...

author: {'steamid': '76561198075403106', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1587420250}
review:
For starters, the Gaelic text option is something i see first time so i have to mention it.
This is a visual novel. It is based on the same name adventure novel by John Buchan. You, basically, "watch" a book. It is not a game in any aspect.
The voiceovers are great and the graphics are like a painting which you would probably hang in your living room. It has a bit slow pace but it is suitable to the story.
The only negative thing i noticed is that in the tutorial it is mentioned that you advance on the story by moving your mouse in a circle clockwise but instead you can do that by just left clicking.
I enjoyed it in general, but my favorite part is the hunt and the people you meet while on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998600599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1586094891}

However, I did have some issues with it. It wouldn't capture my mouse, and the way to cycle through text is absolutely horrid. For the price however, this game is alright, and an interesting spin. Just keep in mind, that THIS IS A VISUAL NOVEL. Lot's of reading and story, even more so than your typical VN. If you're into it, I would buy it, but because of my fighting with the control scheme and mouse actions, I cannot recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989890928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1513553144}
review:
This is more story than game - all of the mechanics are simple actions to advance the story.  I hadn't read the book before playing this, but loved it so much I went and read it for myself.  It's a different experience entirely.

Even reading I could still see the points they hit on, but my own imagination goes another way reading.  The intersection only serves to enrich the experience.  If I had the ability I'd go back and do it in the same order - I played this a few years ago and still think about it all the time.

I only feel compelled to come back and review this because I was hoping these guys had done more, but alas they have not.  So I'm reviewing in the hopes that will one day happen.

Thanks for making an imprint on my life, it was truly amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198047498871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1584144269}
review:
Richard Hannay is a mining engineer who becomes the unlikely witness of a murder of a spy and finds himself involved in a plot to start a war between Russia and Germany. 

This interactive story is a pleasant way to live James Buchan's 1915 book in about 5 hour. I never played a game like this, with no action indee, it's both relaxing and gripping. Unlike Hitchcock's movie adaptation, it follows the original story. I don't really get the point-and-click parts, it resembles to Netflix's "Are you still there" moments. The music is fitting, but the loops are cut terribly, and the final track makes you wonder if you were watching Jason Bourne. Still, it's a very lovely thriller, and it gave me chills many times throughout the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198981428605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1744, 'last_played': 1584282959}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025854444', 'num_games_owned': 1129, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1583700585}
review:
This game is a visual novel, and I believe it would be better to just read the book.
This felt a bit stupid, since it was a bit point and click to keep the story going, and a minigame from time to time to read books, open doors, eat ect. Unnessesary for a visual novel.
I got quite annoyed at the times when you got to choose what info to read up on first. If you stil can choose to read all of it, and it's all relevant to the story, why not just make it a monolog from the main character?
Read the book instead, or get it as an audiobook. This is not a badly made visual novel, but I mostly got annoyed at the slow pacing and need to click the story onwards all the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986277457', 'num_games_owned': 1327, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1624660112}

review: Excellent rendition of a classic "boy's own" story. I've never played an interactive book before but I thought it was a fun format and a way to get a lot of details one tends to gloss over when reading the book in paper format. I had a lot of fun with this and the addition of voice acting and the little extras like newspaper clippings added a lot to that enjoyment. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238011022', 'num_games_owned': 860, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1580664550}
review:
Es una novela, no se juega a nada, no nos enga√±emos. Hay que mover el rat√≥n de vez en cuando, pero poco m√°s. La historia tiene su aquel, claro... ¬°porque es una novela! S√≥lo faltar√≠a que encima fuese mala, pero no, al menos como lectura cumple.
Ideal para practicar ingl√©s avanzado, eso s√≠, con palabros constantes que ampliar√°n tu vocabulario, si te molestas en traducirlos; y puedes enterarte de movidas de principio del siglo XX leyendo los m√∫ltiples e interminables peri√≥dicos que encontrar√°s, que oye, culturiza, ¬øno? ¬øSab√≠ais que las sufragistas iban a los museos a rajar cuadros y se cargaban las ventanas a pedradas por la calle? author: {'steamid': '76561198026631655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1579194593}
review:
The prospect of an interactive novel sounds quite nice, and I know it's a riveting story as I have seen a theatre adaptation of it, but trying to turn it into a computer game simply does not work. The graphics aren't the most impressive, the user interface leaves some things to be desired, and when the mini games are contrived scenes as you're trying to find a few things to click and look at in a bigger scene. They also break up the flow of the story. 

When I got to the place where there is a mini game of moving the mouse in certain patterns just to open your own front door(!) I decided I had had enough.

I mean, seriously, if you are going to make a computer game, you had better make it more exciting than reading the book, but this isn't it. It completely lacks flow or coherence.

The cinematic opening titles were nice, but if I ever want to experience the 39 Steps again, I'll just read the book. It will be a lot more exciting than this "game".

author: {'steamid': '76561198186865498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1578410504}
review:
I'd never played a "visual novel" before but I did enjoy reading John Buchan's "The 39 Steps" some years ago and I've been rather disappointed with various movie adaptations, which don't stick to the source novel very well. This "game" however, does follow the novel closely and is filled the bright, airy adventure of the Scottish borders that appeals to so many fans. There's not much in the way of actual gameplay, and there's no replay value, but there's lots of atmosphere and it really does immerse you in the novel and has excellent production value. 

The game is from 2013 and the end credits (which you must watch for a bonus scene) promises more from Richard Hannay's adventures, but that has yet to come to fruition. There are 20 achievements and trading cards available.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189473109', 'num_games_owned': 582, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1578158496}

As a visual novel, it's pretty good, but there are some points of making people annoyed, like too slow transitions.  Overall, if you really love 39 Steps, it's worth to you; if not, just forgot it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110344533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1576701483}
review:
I was doubting this game at first, because all you have to do in this game is read, listen and click. It doesn't require any thinking at all. You basically read a book in a game. BUT, the intriguing story (combined with art and sound fx) made me finish the game. 

Voice acting is good enough.

There really is no replay value, but made me interested in the novel itself, so there's a chance that I will read it one day.

7/10

Not really much of a game, but I really enjoyed the plot.
