author: {'steamid': '76561198041115695', 'num_games_owned': 1059, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1574000916}
review:
I'm usually a massive fan of visual novel games but 39 steps commits to the "novel" aspect too much. As someone who knew nothing about the original book that the game is based on, the only way that I could get sucked into the game is with a strong opener. I could only bother getting to the second chapter as the game is brutally dry. There are small aspects of interaction such as clicking on things in the environment to get extra details about the setting and characters or do motions with your mouse to mimic the actions of the protagonist but the lack of interactivity wasn't something that I was a big fan of. If you're okay with an experience of essentially just reading a book on steam then this game is for you, but I couldn't get past the monotony and I'm throwing in the towel early.

It's not fair to rate the game overall as it might get interesting later down the line and I didn't finish it, but for people like me who want a little bit more of games like Higurashi or Danganronpa for their VNs I'd give it a pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201820504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1574035923}
review:
I hesitate to even call this an interactive novel.  There are a few times when you need to make certain gestures before you can proceed any further, but you have no real choices to make.  It's like an animated graphic novel you click through.  

I almost gave up on it in the first scene but I am glad I gave it another chance.  It was frustrating at times not to be able to click through the dialogue to speed things up, but once I gave it into the pace, I enjoyed the experience.  The illustrations are wonderful and it was interesting to see how the developers put the game together.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005257487', 'num_games_owned': 1139, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 554, 'last_played': 1573621549}

author: {'steamid': '76561198116194964', 'num_games_owned': 3004, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1572402999}
review:
Gr√°ficos: Eu achei os gr√°ficos muito bonitos, as artes s√£o bem feitas.

Efeitos sonoros: Outro ponto positivo, o jogo possui bel√≠ssimos efeitos sonoros que possibilitam uma imers√£o satisfat√≥ria na historia.

M√∫sica: As musicas presentes tambem possuem excelente qualidade.

Controles: √â um jogo de apontar e clicar, n√£o possui nenhum segredo.

Enredo: A historia √© baseada em um livro, ent√£o basicamente √© um livro interativo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188664927', 'num_games_owned': 1601, 'num_reviews': 385, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1562896351}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AfHUDRVYiVk&list=PLIb_a695uFXCXLgbEdkcPWNlDB2jZ8U4A&index=2
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
Apparently, this is a game recreation of a book by the same name, written back in 1915 by John Buchan.  I looked into the story more after finishing the game, and people seem rather captivated by it, as it's been made into a few movie adaptations and a play.  This may stem more from how this was the theoretical first story centered around fleeing from the police and ne'er-do-wells, which is now a fairly popular sub-genre of thriller movie (man on the run).  


If you're like me though, you never heard of anything about this story in any form before seeing this game.  I'll admit that I'm not really sure what motivated anyone to take a novel and make a game out of it.  In essence, it's simply a visual novel, with a small scattering of things for you to interact with, as you progress through the story.  Seemingly it's so much like other visual novels that one would think it'd be perfectly fine, but I'm not sure that it succeeded overall.  


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
	‚Ä¢ The accompanying background music seems well-suited for the story and game.  I can't speak with any expertise as to whether it's period-specific though.  
	‚Ä¢ I appreciated the inclusion of black and white photographs of people to give more life and authenticity to the era of the game.  
	‚Ä¢ The text was clear and large enough to be easily read by most people.  
	‚Ä¢ May scratch an itch for devoted fans of this story or older literature.


[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
	‚Ä¢ Infrequently, the game puts in a few sections where you have to move the mouse in specific ways, following a pattern, in order to complete an action and progress.  This may have helped break up the monotony if it were used more often, or for more interesting actions, but the most common use of this mechanic was to open doors.  It's so unusual that it's more hilarious than engaging or interesting.  
	‚Ä¢ In the tutorial, the game instructs you to rotate the mouse to either advance or scroll back through the text.  However, you can actually just click the left mouse button to advance text, as would be expected.  The game doesn't tell you this though; I only found out by accident.
	‚Ä¢ Characters aren't actually given a full image.  Aside from a small scattering of black and white photographs, you never get to see what Hannay or anyone else looks like, other than as a vague silhouette.  The VN is short-changing you on the visuals.  
	‚Ä¢ Some of the driest parts I had to read through were the newspaper clippings.  They really dragged the pace down with uninteresting text bombs.  
	‚Ä¢ Occasionally, certain areas of the game are voice-acted, but I never saw any sense on what parts were or weren't.  
	‚Ä¢ I don't think the story is very well-written, and I didn't like the protagonist.


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
I'll always acknowledge that VN games don't tend to be my cup of tea, but I think this one was doomed to failure from the start.  For those who'd want to read so much already, they may as well pick up the original novel and go through it the old-fashioned way.  Others would have the option to watch one of the movie adaptations, which provides much more stimulus, without the need for actively scrolling through so much text.  Even if creative liberties need to be taken for it to be film-friendly, deviating from the story somewhat, I'd have much rather simply watched a movie version of this instead.  The medium of a VN provided me no comparative benefit to observing this story another way, meaning the five hours I spent going through the game could have been spent on watching a couple of the movies.  There's no reason for me to recommend this game, when retelling this 100 year old story has been done better elsewhere.

review:
This visual novel is a good adaption of the book, it stays strictly close to it and it has beautiful visuals to make you more immersed in the story. 
Gameplay wise there's not much to do beside some mouse movement and soundwise everything is simply ok.

If you don't like to read books but are curious of the 39 steps's story, this is a good replacement for it.

As a game it has little to offer but as a visual novel it does his job right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055531472', 'num_games_owned': 1179, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1560586087}
review:
[h1] Long Winded, A Game Only A Fan Could Love	[/h1]
So I know what thrillers are, it's a genre I really enjoy. This... well I'm just going to call it what it is. It's a kinetic novel, not a game. You don't make choices or do anything really. The only interactions the game gives you is clicking or rotating your mouse through text (a strange choice), occasionally he'll stop and you can click on a few things in the room to look closer at them or read them if you'd like to, then there's the odd rotating your mouse or pushing it forward to open a door or box for no reason other than interactivity. 

A fan of the books would love this game, the details go above and beyond to the point where you can read every word of every newspaper if you'd like to. There's also a ton of unnecessary details that the player doesn't, will never need to know, and will forget after playing. It's clear that a fan of the novels made this "game", but they took no consideration for people that have never read the books. If you're coming in blind then it's not thrilling in the slightest, it's long winded and doesn't know a quote I enjoy a lot, "A conversation should be like a short skirt. Long enough to cover the important bits, but short enough to leave them wanting more." This is a good philosophy for story telling too. The reader or in this case player needs a reason to stick around, and they simply don't give you one.

If your a fan of the source material, go nuts, I'm sure you'll have a wonderful time. A newcomer won't find much for themselves here though.

[h1] Pros:	[/h1]
+Mechanics and format that a lot of visual novels could benefit from
+In-depth Detail that fans would love
+A lot of voice acting that isn't bad at all

[h1] Cons:	[/h1]
-Long winded, it doesn't keep you engaged or wanting more
-Not thrilling at all
-Pointless interactivity just for the sake of being interactive
-A lot of the times it wouldn't let me click to go forward on the dialog, I don't know if it has trouble switching between cutscenes and kinetic novel but it liked to tell me no when trying to advance through dialog. If you can't control how fast you're moving through the dialog then there's no point in letting you control it at all. There were many times that I could read a line 8 times over before it let me advance in the text.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975760979', 'num_games_owned': 1239, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1642282452}
review:
This is a hard game to describe, mainly because it isn't really a game, it's like a book you sometimes interact with.
I for one have heard of the book but never read it so this was a great way to expierence the book as it has everything you need in an espionage, spies, murder and intrigue, I can see why it is an often talked about novel.
It's a great gaming expierence and is a must for anyone who likes a game to be a bit cerebal, if your into COD, you may not like this game but if you like an engaging story delivered in a modern way, you will love this.
I have only two small gripes , it sometimes takes a bit to work out what you have to do , which can start off frustrating but percieve with it as you will be thankful you have but why does pressing the right mouse button ( the expected action button ) have to take you out of the game , this does kill the expierence at times which meant I started using my left hand to stop myself doing this, but with something as good as this and the incredible attention to detail , the developers can be forgiven even if they should of play tested this out.
If I had to score it , it would be an 8 that would of been a 9 with the two niggles removed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026048770', 'num_games_owned': 6129, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1559429366}
review:
This is a digital retelling of a classic novel, with fewer gameplay choices than visual novels. It won't be to everyone's taste but it superbly translates the reading experience to the medium in a stylish manner that has its own unique charm. 

The artwork, voice acting, and storytelling are well done, if a bit slow-paced for modern readers/gamers/viewers. The story itself is something of the fore-father to modern thrillers and inspired Ian Flemming's early James Bond novels. It is, however, a much slower burn than modern adventure tales or espionage thrillers, with more in common with the delivery we find in tales of Sherlock Holmes. It took me a bit to get into the flow of it but I'm glad to have had the experience.  

I'd have almost certainly never absorbed this work of fiction had it not been for this digital recreation. In an age where there's more entertainment at our fingertips than any human could consume in a hundred lifetimes, this proves to be an effective, if imperfect, means of capturing the essence of a classic and distilling it in enjoyable, convenient way. I would love to see more novels converted to the gaming medium like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030280204', 'num_games_owned': 2173, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1558152541}
review:
I enjoyed this game a lot, but just so you know what you're getting into - this isn't so much a game as it is a guided retelling of this story. You will spend most of your time looking and beautiful scenery and clicking to advance the lines of text (there is supposedly some feature where you spin your mouse to advance the story but that was not working for me at all). Every so often, you'll hear two (or more) characters exchange dialogue, you'll watch a flashback vignette, or be asked to swirl your mouse around to open doors, eat food, etc. All of these serve to immerse you in the story, and they work well, just don't understand that there is absolutely zero player agency in this game.

One thing I will point out is that many games will "dress up" a story on rails by trying to convince the player they're in the scene by finding interaction points, choosing dialogue options, etc - but The 39 Steps doesn't waste time with that. There is stuff to investigate, but they will clearly highlight it on the screen. And when you're shown a full page of a newspaper, there is a button to click that will highlight the relevant part of the story for you. That was much appreciated and helped to keep the game from getting tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259789863', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1553368833}
review:
"The only thing to distrust is the normal."

Apparently, this game is based on James Buchanan's 1915 novel of the same name, which also influenced the James Bond series. Go figure. I've never read the novel, but maybe I'll give it a whirl someday. Regardless, I enjoy a good piece of interactive fiction from time to time, and I feel like I got what I was looking for with The 39 Steps.

Being more of a visual novel, you can expect to do quite a bit of reading; however, that's made enjoyable by the eye-catching graphics/art style, excellent voice acting, and lovely soundtrack. From walking around foggy London streets to hiking through the Scottish countryside, the music and art combine to really enhance the overall mood. Aside from the reading, most of the game's action sequences revolve around relatively simple scene searches and mouse movements. The latter can feel a bit silly, especially when you're just going through the motions to open a door or something, but it's what you'd expect from a visual novel so I wasn't particularly annoyed. Each scene is also relatively short, which offers the player a break from the "action" (reading).

Definitely recommended for fans of this genre: those who appreciate visual novels, graphic adaptations of novels, etc. I enjoyed The 39 Steps and will probably play it again someday, much like picking up an enjoyable book for another read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083246187', 'num_games_owned': 750, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1555603403}
review:
[i]The 39 Steps[/i] is one of those video games that many will insist isn't a video game. Perhaps more appropriately categorized as a visual novel, it tells a very solid story through on-screen text, narration, dialogue, and artwork in a surprisingly varied amount of styles.

While the main gameplay interaction is simply pressing the right arrow key to cycle lines of text (*see note below), this is broken up with occasional variations on point-and-click, such as scanning newspaper articles, selecting objects in a room, and drawing shapes with the mouse. If it sounds basic and uninteresting, well, it is - but that's not the point of the game. These mechanics only serve to add a bit of spice to the main intent of this experience, which is to sit back, relax, and enjoy a good story.

It won't be everyone's cup of tea, but the plot of [i]The 39 Steps[/i] is well crafted, adapted from a novel written in 1915 by a Scottish author named John Buchan. It follows a simple three act structure, where the main character unwittingly gets tangled up in a political conspiracy, goes on the run from his enemies, and eventually tries to gain the upper hand. Richard Hannay, the protagonist and narrator, is crafty and intelligent, and it's a pleasure to witness how he handles several very dangerous situations through quick thinking and improvisation. Although the pace of the story feels slow due to the calm cadence of its text, it actually moves at a pretty brisk pace, covering a novel's worth of events in the span of about 3 hours. I imagine much of the writing from the book was copied verbatim here, albeit heavily abridged to serve the pace of a game. This is not an edge-of-your-seat thriller, but it's nevertheless an entertaining ride - perfect for a quiet evening or two at home with a cup of tea, enjoyed the same way one would enjoy a good book.

I won't include spoilers here, but my only complaint with the story is its ending - I am again assuming this is kept true to the novel. Story structure was much different 100 years ago, and the third act builds intrigue and mystery in a way that today's standards would demand some sort of interesting twist or confrontation but ultimately falls very flat, followed by an abrupt ending that offers no closure to the characters involved. It's a heavy dud at the end of an otherwise enjoyable tale.

The game's best feature is its historical setting - taking place in 1914 in wartime Europe, the writing and dialogue reflect a strong grasp on the English language as it was used and written at that time, delivered with some superb voice acting. All of the artwork is again period-accurate, mostly delivered in the format of painted stills of European environments in both the city and countryside. Although character art exists in the game, most scenes show people as silhouettes - this is to the game's benefit, since the real focus is on the voice work.

Similar to novels like Mark Danielewski's [i]House of Leaves[/i], the way the text is presented sometimes follows the on-screen action, adding to the drama of a scene in a minimalistic way. Animation is effective where it needs to be. And even though most scenes are composed of stills, there is a vibrant and lively sound effects track present throughout, emphasizing scenes with soundscapes like a bustling train station or a gentle river in a farming village, layered with surprisingly well-arranged music.

This isn't the type of game that can ever hope to receive a showering of praise from today's gaming audience. It's a small-scale, small-budget interactive novel that only takes a few hours to complete. But what it sets out to do it succeeds in doing very admirably. If you enjoy reading novels, there is a good chance you will appreciate the tone and pacing of this interactive story. Were it to have a more fulfilling ending, I would have considered it a near-perfect experience.

*If you are planning on trying this game out, I recommend you ignore the default control tutorial, which has you cycling through text with mouse circles. I found this method unwieldy bordering on broken, and I highly recommend you scroll by using the keyboard arrows.

review:
[h1]BORING[/h1]
I'm fine with "games" that are just digital books with no challenge or choices. But this is boring and looks cheap, with lots of prattling on about old timey England. This was obviously made (on a tiny budget) by fans of The 39 Steps novel/movies and maybe this is worth playing if you're a big fan too, but otherwise it's barely a step up from the terrible games that people gift each on Steam as a joke. If you're tempted by this I would suggest trying [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/381780/80_Days/]80 Days[/url] instead - its writers actually understood the importance of brevity!

author: {'steamid': '76561198074314134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1547109290}
review:
I was very disappointed with this game. They make it sound like it's going to be a very interesting story - a thriller! Inspiration for James Bond! - but it's an absolute bore, and I'm someone who loves reading lots of different genres of novels. Overall, I found the story to be confusing, slow paced, and predictable, and for a "game" that is literally just clicking through text after text after text, it needs to have an amazing and immersive story to make it worthwhile.

Graphics of the scenery were nice, but that's about all I can compliment. The voiceovers were okay but a lot of them had accents that were difficult to understand, with subtitles that were no help. There were parts of the story (usually the dreadful Scottish accents!) that I had no idea what was going on, thanks to the accents and use of dated language. The only "interactive" part of the "game" was doing some different movements with the mouse (to do things like open a door...) so you're not constantly clicking or rotating clockwise to progress the text. It took me three hours to complete, which I had to do in several sittings as I kept on getting bored while waiting for something exciting to happen, and there were no missable achievements.

I don't like to leave a negative review, but I wish I hadn't wasted my time on this game. I feel like the summary is a bit misleading and I wanted to leave a negative review to give potential buyers a different take on it, as the summary and positive reviews lead me to buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025812458', 'num_games_owned': 1977, 'num_reviews': 445, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1549352103}
review:
Admittedly I haven't watched The 39 Steps directed by Alfred Hitchcock, nor have I read the original novel by John Buchan. Either way, I'm gonna go out on a limb and say that this adaptation by The Story Mechanics is not the most worthwhile version of the story. The pacing here is tragically slow. The transitions and interactive elements are also just mundane. So essentially everything that would make this adaptation on Steam worthwhile doesn't really impress me that much. 

If you want to experience The 39 Steps, I think you could find a better paced and more interesting story in either the novel or the film. This interactive visual novel is modern but uninteresting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972465344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1546305644}
review:
So, this "Digital Adaptation" of a novel, as they call it, is an interesting beast. The story itself, which is the main point of a visual novel, is good, as would be expected as it is based on a real novel.

That being said, since there is not much gameplay involved, the judgement of this "game" is then mostly on the technical execution side. Let's just go through my experience:

I launch the game, and dreadully I notice that it goes into full screen mode using 1920x1080 resolution, downsizing the desktop from the native 3840x2160, causing all open previously windows, Steam included, to be moved and resized. So the first thing in the main menu I am looking for graphics options to change the resolution, in vain. A bit upset of this setback, I start the story.

The game starts with a kind of a tutorial on the controls, telling to make a clockwise motion with mouse to progress on the text, and use left mouse click to progress at the end of a scene. A bit awkward way to do it. Then it explains that the game is mostly pointer-free and that if you see the mouse cursor, that's the cue that it's time to interact with it. And the first scene is to click on your Apartment to go in there.

At this point, since the wrong resolution is taking away the enjoyment already, I hit Escape in hopes of a in-game menu that might contains some settings to fix it. Instead, it brings a menu containing Events, Cards, Bookmarks, and Extras. I click through them but don't find any options to change the resolution, so in the Events screen I see one tile is unlocked, presuming that to be the start of the game, so I click on that, and choose to Play. Apparently doing that just skipped the rest of the tutorial and went directly to the first chapter of the actual story. Later I find out that completing the tutorial would yield one of the in-game awards, and there is no way to get back to the tutorial. So thanks, trying to fix a technical issue just permanently banned me from getting one unlockable on this profile. Whatever, let's continue the story.

Despite having missed the tutorial, I quickly learn the rest of the game mechanics, how to interact with objects, and how the story plays out. Not really a fan of the mouse movement to progress on text, I try to figure out alternative ways to progress and find out that simply clicking the left mouse button appears to do the same as the mouse movement, but unlike waving with the mouse, it also works for the end of the scene, for what it was for instructed in the tutorial. Still, not keen on keeping my hand on the mouse all the time for a game that's mostly about reading text, I tried pressing Enter (or Return, as they call it) and that seemed to work too!

Except, at some points I notice that if I press Enter, the game doesn't just progress to the next piece of text, but totally skips the scene. This seemed random to me, and there was even a part where using keyboard didn't progress forward but mouse click did. Too bad that the game is about the text, and this made me miss some of it! I didn't see an easy way to go back. Also, because of this random scene-skipping, I encountered a bug that after the end of an Event, skipping the final scene caused the event completion achievement not unlocking, and also the next Event tile stayed locked and black, even though the story itself progressed forward. Funnily, at the end of the game I got the achievement for completing all the events, even though one event completion achievement was still locked due to this bug!

At some point I had to Alt-Tab out of the game. On first try it worked all fine, just with the inconvenience of resolution switching back and forth, causing window sizing and scaling problems, but on the next try the game just froze and I couldn't go back in. Fortunately the progress is auto-saved constantly, so no progress was lost. At this point I went through the Steam Discussion for the game and found out that you can change the in-game screen resolution by editing Windows Registry. A bit cumbersome for such a basic setting, but at least I managed to make the game run with the native resolution now.

Also later on I found out that in the Extra menu there is a section explaining the controls, and there it says that Left and Right arrow keys are aliases for the mouse-controlled text progression, and Return is for skipping the scene. So it was somehow my fault for not finding this information first and only learning the hard way to refrain from reading the text using Enter (as it didn't always skip the whole scene...!) Also in the Controls section it told me that Backspace goes back to previous scene. Oh would that also have been handy to know at the times I mistakenly skipped something. I wonder why the keyboard controls weren't mentioned at all during the tutorial? (yes, I did then replay the tutorial with different player profile to see how that part goes through)

At least I managed to get all the Steam achievements, thanks to the ability to jump back to any scene from the Events menu, so I jumped back to the end of the event where I bug-skipped the ending, to unlock the last thing. Still I am missing some of the in-game unlockables for this profile, including the tutorial completion, which apparently is impossible to get if you happen to skip it by mistake. Normally I would go replay a game to unlock the rest of the collectibles, and in this case to read the scenes I missed because of non-explained controls, but the way the story is told is putting me off.

The actual story text is not that plentiful, to tell what's happening with the protagonist, usually a few sentences per scene, but then all the unnecessary text, such as newspaper articles that have nothing to do with the plot, can have many pages of text to be read. I would have expected the opposite, and would have loved to read more of the feelings and environment, as I presume would have been the case in the original text novel. I am only guessing that the authors of the game tried to minimize the text to the reader, and use the artwork to replace much of the environmental description.

So, since the way the story was presented was suboptimal, and due to all the technical issues that would have been basic to fix, I cannot recommend the game as it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067941108', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1562257070}
review:
I find it hard to recommend this. This is not a game, it is an interactive audio book, with the "interactions" consisting of some really weak attempts to engage the player beyond just clicking ahead for the next line of text to appear.
The art style is simplistic and often feels half finished or rushed, which sucks when the semi pretty pictures makes up almost your entire experience listening to the story. 
Based on the novel by John Buchan writen in 1915, the story reads like a old timely spy thriller radio play, and is interesting enough once you get into it. 
Voice acting is good, with some hilarious british gentleman action and some frankly unintelligible scottish accents. 
The music is used effectively to create some tension but only during a handful of infrequent moments. 
This game simply lack any interesting ideas and should have looked way more detailed.
Get it cheap.

CLEARTIME: Around 4 hours to 100% with no missable achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079494546', 'num_games_owned': 1185, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1544727980}
review:
Its a visual novel, where you have absolutely no choice whatsoever, just a spectator of the story. I felt that I'm Stanley from The Stanley Parable, clicking where I have to...

Cons:
- The bad part is that the story is nowhere close to good, every action has little to no consequence on the hero.
- Too bad they decided to use siluettes as characters, it tore away the personalities of them.
- Its unnecessarily slow, it kept me waiting for too long between cutscenes
- The chapter menu came out after every chapter (so every ~12 minutes)

Pro:
+ The voice acting was mostly good
+ The dialects was on point (I'm glad that the subtitle kept it fonetic, so you still barely understand it)
+ The art was decent
+ The subtitle was creatively put on the screen

author: {'steamid': '76561198091030601', 'num_games_owned': 807, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1394, 'last_played': 1544372029}
review:
The original novel written by Scottish author John Buchan in 1915 and is a classic piece of modern literature.  Hitchcock did a stunning film based upon it in 1935.  Dating the story is important in appreciating the game itself.  The game pays tribute in both its artistic style and dialogue to its roots.  Rich watercolors make the background quite enjoyable.  The voice acting feels authentic for the period being presented.  

I believe I received The 39 Steps as part of a bundle.  I would not personally pay full price for it.  It does not take very long to complete and I'd classify it more as a visual novel than a game.  The "puzzles" are nothing more than mimicking a few strokes, the plot is completely linear.  The UI suggests making some sweeping circles of the mouse to go forward/back that don't work quite as intended as some other reviewers have noted.

Still, I am going to recommend this game.  I wouldn't pay more than $5 for it personally, so I advocate waiting for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013224267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1514676698}
review:
[h1] ‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü: *‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü:*    A click-through adventure novel   *:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß*:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß[/h1]

An adaptation of a historical adventure thriller, The 39 Steps is best enjoyed slowly, as it really offers no choices but plays more like an audiobook that matches your pace. The characters appear only as silhouettes, which seems hard to keep track of but nevertheless works effectively, allowing for the same expressive imagination as reading a book. There are several instances where the protagonist engages in investigation of his surroundings, which will manifest as close-ups to crime scenes or post Edwardian-era inspired newspaper clippings. The game is not terribly long, overall, but it struck just the right amount for me as I had been getting anxious to finish towards the denouement. 

[h1]‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü: *‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü:* „ÄÄPROS„ÄÄ *:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß*:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß[/h1]

‚ùß Fantastic voice acting - very clever use of dialects all over the UK, and the fluidity of some characters' abilities to switch between accents really brings the feeling of a spy thriller to life. Really, worth it for this alone if you wait for a sale.

‚ùß Feels appropriate for the period, and takes an interesting approach into a believable, slightly alternate history.

‚ùß Decent variety of environments. Some are hand-drawn, others are stock photos with some photo effects to mask them. Nothing really stands out, but it's not unpleasant to look at for hours. Often very pretty, better than most cartoon styles in my opinion.

‚ùß Fairly atmospheric, between the sound effects, music and constant feeling of danger and mistrust. 

‚ùß I appreciate the writing and that the descriptive text tends to be much better than most visual novels - again, likely because this is an adaptation.

‚ùß Occasionally very thrilling - some scenes gripped me so much, paired with sound effects, that I really felt compelled to see the chapters through.


[h1]‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü: *‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü:* CONS *:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß*:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß[/h1]

‚ùß The protagonist, Richard Hannay, is completely odious and unlikeable in my opinion. He can be said to have a personality, at the very least, even if it is arrogant and entitled. It's tolerable, but mostly I feel I have to bear through him to appreciate the rest of the story.

‚ùß Periodically very tedious, even for the patient. Some scenes are unskippable, text speed and transitions are slow. Don't rush through. Enjoy it with a cup of tea, or you won't enjoy it at all.

‚ùß Perhaps it is because the game must necessarily lack the same depth as the book, the last half-hour felt distinctly unsatisfying, underscored largely because (endgame spoiler) [spoiler]the protagonist spends an egregious amount of time doubting something that should be obvious[/spoiler], although it does fit well enough into the spy theme. It just felt like a very slow end to an otherwise more exciting pace. [spoiler]Then again, the narrative always indicates that we should trust nothing, and such misdirections and disguises happen all throughout.[/spoiler]

[h1]‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü: *‚úßÔΩ•Ôæü:* CONCLUSIONS *:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß*:ÔΩ•Ôæü‚úß[/h1]

Likely not for everyone, including those who typically like visual novels. Still, it is a nice change of pace from the typical anime style on Steam, and at times thrilling enough to make me want to take a look at the original book.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078278016', 'num_games_owned': 301, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1542055794}
review:
So, this is something you can enjoy, but calling it a game is a bit of a stretch. Its strongest point is the story, but the story is based on a novel written over 100 years ago, so that's not exactly a compliment to the production of this game.

The "gameplay" is to a great degree a very passive and patience-testing experience. There is virtually zero animation and the text and scene transitions are slow. The game is minimally interactive and feels dead. They also tried to reinvent the wheel with the UI a little bit. Thankfully, everything was divided into chapters, which made it easier to play and finish. I suggest we add a new tag called "Patience Training" just for the sake of this game.

Also, giving out 100% achievements just for playing the game is very dull and unimaginative.

But nevertheless, if one can look past all this, overall the game did manage to have a good enough atmosphere (the voice acting and sound design were superb) and to leave a memorable impression. Having completed it, I can say that I have a fond memory of it and that I would play it again. But I would play it again in the same way I would read a book again, so it's actually a very confusing feeling.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104194390', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1537847398}
review:
[h1]Soy mentor en Steam!![/h1]
[url]http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31570421/[/url]

The 39 Steps es una novela visual basada en la novela de misterio/suspense de John Buchan de 1915. La historia y el texto est√°n intactos: poco antes del estallido de la Primera Guerra Mundial, el ex oficial del ej√©rcito Richard Hannay se establece en Londres. Su estado mental cambia literalmente de la noche a la ma√±ana cuando un vecino, Franklin Scudder, se refugia en su apartamento y revela que ha tropezado con un complot alem√°n para asesinar al primer ministro griego y robar los planes de Gran Breta√±a para el estallido de la Gran Guerra. Cuando Scudder es asesinado unos d√≠as despu√©s, Hannay cree que es el pr√≥ximo. √âl huye hacia el campo, esquivando varios intentos en su vida mientras trata de revelar el cifrado que utiliz√≥ Scudder para encriptar sus notas sobre la trama alemana.

La versi√≥n de The 39 Steps de Story Mechanics combina texto e im√°genes para hacer que la historia de Buchan cobre vida. Te mueves de escena en escena, cada uno muy bellamente ilustrado. Los efectos de sonido hacen eco, incluyendo pasos, respiraci√≥n pesada, traqueteos de trenes y apertura y cierre de puertas. Hay bits animados ocasionales que juegan puntos de trama. Algunos interludios presentan una actuaci√≥n de voz de alta calidad respetuosa con los personajes de Buchan. Un punto notable es que sus personajes humanos est√°n representados por siluetas. Nunca ves con claridad la cara de Hannay, o la de Scudder, que deber√≠an ser buenas noticias para cualquier persona que no le guste las adaptaciones de libro a pel√≠cula porque estropean la visi√≥n del lector sobre los personajes del libro.

Es una maravillosa adaptaci√≥n que rinde los m√°s altos respetos a su material fuente. Ser√≠a genial ver algunos m√°s cl√°sicos de la misma manera.

review: The 39 Steps est√° mais pr√≥ximo de ser um livro digital do um jogo de videogame, ainda assim a experi√™ncia vale a pena. O livro √© bem escrito e a narrativa √© consistente, some a isso as belas ilustra√ß√µes, a trilha sonora e alguma intera√ß√£o com o ambiente e voc√™ tem uma obra √∫nica, gostosa de apreciar (n√£o vale jogar com pressa) e que ir√° te entreter por v√°rias horas. Se voc√™ aprecia hist√≥rias de suspense e/ou espionagem, sabe aproveitar jogos com um ritmo mais lento e est√° tranquilo com a ideia de apenas acompanhar o personagem principal, da mesma forma como faria com um livro, recomendo que comece a ler, ou melhor, jogar, o quanto antes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059030698', 'num_games_owned': 1460, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1536242774}
review:
John Buchan's short story has stood the test of time, and through its various adaptations on screen and in other popular media it has come to be considered as one of the first (and best) examples of an espionage - detective novel ("shocker" as Buchan liked to call it). 
This digital adaptation worths every click of your mouse (it needs to be said, you won't be doing anything more complicated than this!). Visually, the hand-painted scenes carry the spirit of the book faitfully, and my recommendation is to enjoy this reading of the 39 steps under dim light, preferably in one winter, rainy night sitting. The developers have made a very thorough research in the historical setting of the novel, and a number of collectables during the game can be used as short but very informative references to the social and cultural context of early 20th century Britania on the eve of the 'Great War'. From imperial maps and local Scottish accents to the anti-semitism that unfortunately can be found in Buchan's and many of his contemporaries' worldview, this amazing visual novel will serve as a history seminar to those willing to discover its rich texture. Enjoy it as if every click is the turn of a page, and if you have not done so already try and grab a copy of the book. 
Achievements come naturally as you progress, and will pop up even when you are offline, but collecting and reading both sides of the in-game cards is far more rewarding and entertaining. 
I wish all visual novels were as well-researched, inspired and perfectly executed as this one. 
Highly recommended and I will soon check out the developer's new adventure called 'Beckett'.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970677811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1534802883}
review:
I wouldn't really call this a game, but it is entertaining. 

It's a good conspiracy story, and the illustrations are beautiful. 

Beatable it in just a few hours even if reading/watching all sequences.  Guaranteed 100%.

I played it completely on a tablet and all menus and gameplay were fully functional.

The 39 Steps an interactive multimedia story; kind of a mixture of audiobook, e-book, picturebook and even some short videos.  There are no decisions to be made, you are just watching it play out. Occasionally there is a tracing activity for when the main character does actions within the story, but otherwise it's just clicking between sequences.  If you're into interactive stories then it's worth a play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096942945', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1529653392}
review:
The 39 Steps - Formless Review

Story Mode Completed - Yes
Achievement Completion - 100%

Story: 8/10

Based on the novel, the game has a really strong story which is told through fantastic voice acting. The chapters are broken up in neat segments which makes for easy saving and returning to the game at a later time. The story is gripping though it has it's downfall as you essentially have little choice or interactability in comparison with other point and click story-orientated games. For a game based on a novel, it makes for a great story and an enjoyable journey.

Mechanics: 4/10

Simplistic mechanics, similar to other games of the genre. As the story follows a linear narrative and offers little choice, the mechanics boil down to simple point and click, scrolling through walls of text and occasionally listening to the voice overs. Between reading and dialogue, there's little to do, not much for puzzles or interactability. The game leads you down a rather straigh path though the story makes up for it.

Aesthetics: 7/10

The art style is appealing and easy on the eye. There's not much eye candy or flashy scenes that will have you on the edge of your seat, though combined with the strong narrative, the art work allows for a pleasurable experience which is easy to follow. Nothing too special but definitely a pretty game.

Overall - 8/10

If you can play a game entirely for the story and a simple but enjoyable journey, this game is great. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121219566', 'num_games_owned': 1072, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1494081537}
review:
Nice little game made after what i imagine is an interesting book. The voice acting sounds amazingly professional, the music is very good but the best part of the game is the art. It's the most immersive part of the game, it changes around from cut scenes to gameplay and the art fits every situation perfectly
I don't know how much the game follows the books story since I haven't read it, but i wish there were more games made after books like this simply because it feels very polished, like the game knows what it wants, where it wants to go.
The one con i can think of is the price tag, as the game is very short and doesn't have much replay value, I'm a bit slow and it took me 4.5 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1530690283}
review:
Tags: Adventure - VN - Visual Novel 
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Worth a check but not a permanent collection spot. Good characters, well presented, but low interactivity, no replayability and very abrupt disappointing ending. 

Effectively presented historical thriller slideshow with quality voiceovers and sound effects. Very little interactiviity. Short. Ending felt abrupt and unsatisfying.

The 39 steps starts with three or four lengthier chapters, setting up the base of the story. There are enough plot hooks, characterizations and intense quality conversation to hold attention. The dialogue felt credible, historically credible, accents matched. The art was relaxing and transitioned slowly and elegantly between scenes. Very little use of animation was present, but on the rare occasions that it was present, it was done tastefully and it enhanced the experience.

The maps were well done and gave a good grasp of the location of the character along the journeying. However, the social maps, were not so well constructed. The journal was cryptic and decoding it was done through QTE's and a poorly described deciphering method. The newspaper were filled with details but could not be zoomed in comfortably enough to read any of them and summoning the text though the unsatisfying interface often led to seemingly pointless bits of political insight and rivalries being reported on about the paper.

This is meant to turn into some sort of TInker Tailor Soldier Spy scenario with the uncovering of spies, and a lot of disguises, psychological misdirection and the like. The game also has a very faint hint of cthulhu to it, with some of your antagonists being increasingly described as having certain odd quirks of behaviors, uncommon talents and whatnot.

The game ends very abruptly at the end of a chapter as you foil an intelligence leak outside the coutnry using the journal from the intro then the game cuts off to credits immediately. While the game did not leave a ton unexplained, it just did not feel like the buildup leading up to it, slow and detailed that it was, would simply fall flat anticlimactically the way it has.

This, in short, is a more enjoyable game than say Alter Ego. While Alter Ego had decent historical characters, arguably better looking environments, nice fluff art, and equally good if not better voice acting, it also had a lot of pixelhunting, grocery list crossing type detecting sleuth hunts that left you frustrated and in need of a walktrhough. In comparison the 39 steps was much more relaxing. The game might not had been very interactive but it concentrated on what it did and it did well at it. The problem is that it does not feel like a complete package either. While Alter Ego was just rushed out unfinished I am not sure what the deal is with the 39 steps. Perhaps this is in fact a whole story but with the slideshow presentation too many details were cut out from the book and it does not impact the same way. Or maybe it too was cut short. After all the chapters did seem to become shorter and shorter as the game progressed where by the end you just wondered why they even stuck with that structure at all anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327367911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1529827151}
review:
Wow! An extaordiinary historically accurate spy thirller that is thorougly entertaining and worthwhile to read, a real page turner, equal to anything from Ludlum, Fleming, Clancy. It's "James Bond" meets "Downton Abbey", lol. Probably helped that I'm from South Africa, an old Brttish Empire Colony, with a love for history., and spy novels, so I could relate well. This game and story will rival any Bourne movie today.

Pros - Thrilling graphic novel, great price, historically accurate, superb voice acting, great game mechanics, awesome art and music.
Cons -  Liniar path so no choices, but still a great story with a satisfying plot and game mechanics that makes up for it..

Rreflection and glimpses of a much simpler time when we were also under The Crown (without talking politics, it may have been better if we stayd there, lol.).  Hoping for lots more like this from the devs. One of the best spy visual novels I've ever read. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198053495444', 'num_games_owned': 4114, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1529246238}
review:
Looking through a lot of the reviews I think a lot of the people who left negative reviews just aren't into visual novels and maybe weren't aware of what they were when they got into this one. This isn't a typical point & click with puzzles to solve. It isn't a hidden object game or a choose your own adventure story. It is quite literally a novel that has been digitally enhanced with a bit of sound effects, artwork, voice acting, and maybe the occasional mouse "task" like moving it a certain direction or clicking in a certain place. It isn't meant to challenge you, just to engage you more deeply as you read a really great story.

Now for my review:

Pros:
This is the most brilliant way I have seen a visual novel presented so far. I really enjoyed this. I thought it was very well done actually. To other devs who are looking to do a visual novel or as this dev has coined it a "digital adaptation" of thier novel or story, get this and learn from it. This is how you do it right. The art was beautifully done as was the voice acting. There was just enough movement and visualization to not take away from the text, and it wasn't just the reader left clicking endlessly through text like a lot of visual novels. 

At first I was a bit annoyed by the rotation of the mouse to progress the text but once I got used to it I quite liked it. It added a movement and removed the constant drone of clicks from my reading the story. Also, I found that if it bothers you that much you can still click instead of rotate and it will progress you through the same way as if you had rotated, you're just not able to reverse this way. 

The story itself kept me engaged. This is really going to be based on your personal taste. I love a good story about crime and espionage, if you need some romance and teen drama to keep you interested then this probably isn't the tale for you. 

I was very thankful to be able to read what the voice actors were saying, even when we maybe shouldn't have needed to. Some of the words and phrases took me a minute to figure out because the dialects and accents were so strong, but they were very fitting to the story and it just made it work even better, so that isn't a complaint. 

The artwork and visualization mixed with the sound effects were amazing. There was a point where I actually had to grab a blanket and cover up because the dreary London rain had made me chilly even though it's the dead of a hot muggy summer where I live. Really well done.

Cons:
In order to give some constructive criticism I will say that there are times in the story the voice acting echoes and glitches a bit, but other than that I completely enjoyed every moment of it. 

I will say I think the price point is too high. This is probobly the best visual novel I've experiences so far, but the most I've ever paid for one was $5, this at full price is 3 times that. The right audience still might be willing to pay that much for this though...it is really well done. I'm not even sure where I got this from, I'm thinking it was in a bundle of keys I bought or possibly one I traded for in a group I'm in, but I know I would have never paid full price for it and that's a shame because I would have missed out on something awesome had it not come my way through a less expensive route. I would have never been able to justify the cost to myself though knowing the genre, even though it is one I enjoy, having not "played" it first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995421497', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1528684869}
review:
[b][u]5 Things You Should Know about [i]The 39 Steps[/i][/u][/b]
[b]What Is It?[/b]
This game is actually a book, in digital form.  It's an adventure game of the "no choices to make" variety, so don't come here expecting to [i]do things[/i].  It's based on a 1915 spy/mystery novel of the same name (also made into a movie in 1935, directed by Alfred Hitchcock.)

[b]What's The Best Part?[/b]
It's quite a good read.  If you're looking to get the same feeling out of a video game that you'd get from reading an [i]actual book,[/i] then this is it.  Only with beautiful artwork and decent sound effects mixed in to enhance the atmosphere.

The dialogue spoken throughout the story is fully voice acted - and quite well, I thought - whereas the internal monologue of the main character is just text on screen.  It creates an interesting duality, to listen to some things and read others.

[b]What's The Worst Part?[/b]
The controls, as explained at the beginning, are a bit odd.  Rotate the mouse clockwise to advance the text?  Rotate counterclockwise to go back?  What?  Thankfully, you don't actually have to do that.  You can just left-click anywhere to advance the text, which is much more intuitive.  I'm not sure why the game didn't mention that.

[b]Will I Like It?[/b]
+ Classic spy thriller
+ A contemporary vision of 1914 England (the book was written in the time its story was set.)
+ Beautiful art
+ Decent voice acting

- Weird controls (not sure why they bothered, given the alternate controls make so much more sense)

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
The 39 Steps is the first in a series of novels by the same author.  Sadly, it doesn't look like any more of them are coming in game form, given that this game was first released in 2013 and nothing new has been heard since.  I would've liked to have seen them, but I suppose I'll have to settle for reading them on paper.

This has been a 5TYSK review. (#0044)

author: {'steamid': '76561198063825413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 798, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1528311959}
review:
Es ist die Umsetzung des gleichnamigen Spionageromans von John Buchanan aus dem Jahr 1915 als Visual Novel.

Der Roman des Schotten, der es im britischen Weltreich bis zum Generalgouverneur Kanadas schaffte, gilt als Weltliteratur. Zumindest so, wie es in dieser Adaption r√ºberkommt, kann ich dies nicht begreifen. F√ºr mich ist der Roman eine haneb√ºchene, billige Geschichte, die zudem den Staub von √ºber 100 Jahren so erfolgreich angesammelt hat, dass es besser gewesen w√§re, ihn allenfalls noch literaturhistorisch zu betrachten.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1404546637

Dabei beginnt es relativ spannend mit einem Mord. Aber die Verschw√∂rung, die da aufgedeckt wird, konnte ich bald nicht mehr ernst nehmen. In dieser Geschichte wimmelt es von unglaublichen Zuf√§llen, die der Hauptperson, Richard Hannay, mal so, mal so widerfahren. Selbst in der Einsamkeit Schottlands begegnet er genau immer den Leuten, die von Bedeutung sind. Die fast √ºberm√§chtige deutsche Agententruppe, die, wie f√ºr Deutsche √ºblich, immer nach einem genauen, finsteren Plan arbeiten, und am Vorabend des Ausbruchs des ersten Weltkrieges wichtige Informationen erbeuten wollen, finde ich ein √ºbles Stereotyp. Aber dieser Plan war so absurd, dass es eigentlich nur f√ºr einen Groschenroman gut ist.

Sehr interessant gemacht ist die Darstellung des britischen Lebens von 1914 mit dem Obrigkeitsdenken, dem Gentlemangehabe, dem British-Empire-√úberlegenheits-Getue.

Das Buch wurde auch von dem ber√ºhmten britischen Rgissuer Alfred Hk. (dessen Name Steam uns nicht schreiben l√§sst) 1935 verfilmt, wo es aber wesentlich unterhaltsamer zu sein scheint.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1404548065

Wie dem auch sei, ich fand die ganze Sache bald mehr als m√ºhselig. Die wenigen Interaktionen k√∂nnen kaum als Interaktion bezeichnet werden. Man muss vielleicht mal 2, 3 Sachen auf dem Screen finden oder soll Mausbewegungen durchf√ºhren.

K√ºnstlerisch haben die Entwickler allerdings eine gute Leistung abgeliefert. Es sind offenbar alles gemalte Bilder von oft sehr sch√∂nen Landschaften und H√§usern. Aber Handlungen werden nur angedeutet und die Personen sind nur als Schatten dargestellt, was ich nicht so toll fand.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1404547380

F√ºr uns Deutsche anspruchsvoll sind die unterschiedlichsten britischen Akzente, die die offenbar sehr guten Sprecher, an den Tag legen. Meist konnte ich aber gut erahnen, wor√ºber gerade gesprochen wurde.

Die Musik ist recht passend stimmungsvoll.

Die Steuerung ist sehr einfach. Warum man nun aber kreisf√∂rmige Bwegungen machen muss, um bei Text zur√ºckzubl√§ttern, ist mir ein R√§tsel. Vorw√§ts kommt man gl√ºcklicherweise auch mit einem Mausklick.

Es gibt viele Errungenschaften, die alle automatisch freigeschaltet werden.

Pro & Contra:

+ Aufwendig und sch√∂n gestaltete Visual Novel

- Eine (wie ich finde) unglaubw√ºrdige, stereotypenbehaftete, angestaubte Geschichte

Wertung: 4/10

Wenn sie den ganzen Aufwand, den sie offensichtlich betrieben haben, auf die Umsetzung einer (f√ºr mich) spannenden Geschichte verwendet h√§tten, w√ºrde ich es empfehlen k√∂nnen.

review: Prepare to experience the original man-on-the-run thriller in a completely new way. This is a digital adaptation of John Buchan's incredible book (inspiration to Ian Fleming's James Bond!). Be transported back to 1914 London, where Richard Hannay finds himself framed for a murder he didn't commit. Now he must escape the Capital and stay alive long enough to solve the riddle of The Thirty-Nine Steps. There are secrets to be discovered, locations to be explored and - above all - an incredible tale to be told in this ground-breaking interactive novel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198369097470', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1561681508}
review:
I was so wrong about this "game". At first, i played a little, for like, 13 minutes and closed it because i got bored. Never played it again. Until a few days ago, when i was really bored, and i wanted something different. I tried this one, and oh boy, i was so wrong about it. After [spoiler]Scubber's death[/spoiler], i was really interested in the story. 
The voice acting is so good. Better than some actual AAA games. The atmosphere, the characters, everything in this game is unique. Something that i have never played, or better said, experinced before. 
I usually don't judge a book by it's cover, but with this one i did, and i quite regret that. 
The game is pretty short, it tool me 6 hours because i read everything in the game. Every dialog, card, or award. It's very interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981907008', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1524925441}
review: Great visual novel based on a book from the beginning of the previous century. Nice visual style that makes the most of a limited budget, invigorating soundtrack that gets especially exciting during the "action" set pieces and some of the best voice acting I have ever heard in an indie game. It doesn't have any replay value after you finish it in about 3 - 4 hours. But I would say for 10 bucks, which is the prize of a movie ticket, it is definitely worth your time.

[b]EN[/b]
The 39 Steps is a good adventure game worth recommending, based on a movie and book with same title. The story is interestingly told, it keeps you in suspense, however, this is the kind of games where you read a lot. In the game, we see well painted images, nice graphics, but sometimes some mistakes occur, although it runs very smoothly, setting to your screen resolution by itself. The original version is in English, so without knowing it well, there is nothing to try, unless it will get translated into other languages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144204776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1522946333}
review: If you enjoy interactive, visual novels and pre-WWI espionage, then this game is for you. The story is based on the 1915 adventure novel The Thirty-Nine Steps by John Buchan. The game consists of a lot of storytelling and very little interaction other than clicking to continue. The entire game should take roughly 3-4 hours to complete, with that being said, I personally do not feel that the current $14.99 price tag is appropriate. I obtained the game through a bundle and would have to say that $4.99 would be a more reasonable price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022266051', 'num_games_owned': 3243, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1521086710}
review:
[h1]What a great interactive story![/h1]

I thought this was really well done.  It's kind of like part audiobook, part point-n-click, and part Ken Burn's PBS documentary.  It's telling a well-written story with voice actors for all the characters and you read just the descriptive narrative lines.  And while the voice actors read to you, the still scene slightly shifts or characters fade in/out.

And while this may sound boring, it's not.  It's a very intriguing story that is presented in a very simplistic, but appealing way.

There's a few scenes where you also (albeit minimally) interact with the scene.  Such as clicking on the location where the character is proceeding, or clicking on various objects in a room to get more background information on items, events, and characters, all to progress the story along.

Several times, other characters tell stories of events and these are presented as (animated) old-timey silent films complete with the ubiquitous flickering light and smudged filmstrip debris.  Very cool.

[h1]I thought the voice actors were great and I certainly enjoyed listening to this [b]4.6 hr story[/b].  I look forward to more stories presented like this!  8 out of 10.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198029220607', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1520711192}
review:
The developers did quite a good job capturing the atmosphere of the occuring events. The mixture of sound and imagery really makes a great experience, even (or especially) for someone who hasn't read the original book.

The player (reader) most of the time experiences Hannay's inner monologue, (which is seldomly more than one sentence at a time which makes it quite an easy read), the pacing is good and the well thought-out usage of visual effects on some sequences adds up to the experience of Hannay's feelings.
The audio work for dialogues and backgrounds really stands out and may certainly match the quality of a well directed radio drama. There's even been decent work put into stereophony for in- and outdoor scenes, which I really appreciate. The voice actors did a swell job giving their characters specific and recognizeable personalities and the accents sounded really convincing to me (as a non-british/scottish speaker).
Some little audio bugs can occur however, the background audio sometimes loops longer than it's supposed to or (very seldomly) cuts out entirely. It's worth mentioning but not too grave - also, a quick reload of the chapter usually fixes the issue.
The painted backgrounds are pretty decent most of the time and they manage to catch the atmosphere of the ongoing scene. They sometimes vary in quality and even art style and the SFX are nothing to ride home about. But again, it's nothing too dramatic. I respect and appreciate the work put into them.

So yes, I can recommend this. I can say that I normally don't read a lot of books but I got enjoyment out of it. So what's your excuse for not having given it a try yet? ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198040494331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1520472138}
review:
I have way to many games on steam and I'm trying to play a minimum of 1 hour in every game, afterwards I will write my review! 

Going into this I had no idea what to really expect I wasn't sure if it was a game or just a graphic novel. This leans more towards a telling of a story than a game however that doesn't make it any less of an experience. If youre looking for a sort of interactive story then this is it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045630846', 'num_games_owned': 1476, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1503190844}
review:
It seemed dull at first, but the story draws you in and provides an enjoyable, period piece, visual novel.

Achievements were broken under Linux/SteamOS when I played, but worked fine under Windows. The Linux install can be fixed to make achievements work, as it's only related to a broken/outdated steam library distributed with the game. There are instructions in the game's discussion forum for fixing this under Linux.

6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197998817967', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 232, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1518121827}
review:
This is a sort of interctive... presentation. It's based on the novel of same name and apaprently stays true to original. And, well, that's it, there's the story, and then some extra distractions like ocassional QTE. All dialogue is voice-acted, and the environments and details depicted seem very period-apropriate and well-researched.

I really hated it even though I went trough the whole thing, even if I skipped most of stuff by the second half. See... it's like reading a book. A book with pretty pictures and voice-acted dialogue, which can be neat, but also with some unskippable dramatic pauses, QTEs and screen transition animations. See, while this format may have some potential, probably, I really prefer to read at my own pace, and quite many of the interactive or visual aspects distract from it - imagine if you were reading a book and then instead of just flipping the next page you gotta wait a moment for letters to pop up because it's creator really wanted you to take a moment there for extra drama. It's obnoxious! I would have really appreciated if there was an option to make transitions immediate. That would have made this quite a more enjoyable experience for me, seeing I never got a chance to read the original novel so the plot did grip me,

author: {'steamid': '76561198028057114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1517693575}
review:
Great Voice acting and visual assistance to enhance the story. The sequences with mouse movements can sometimes interfere with the immersion into the story when they are too long, but otherwise it was a great digital adaptation of an old story. This was a fun way to bring it to a different medium and the developers should be proud of the work they have done. 

Overall I greatly enjoyed the story and the experience this visual novel provided.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198052327864', 'num_games_owned': 3735, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1516602302}
review:
Interaktive lineare Geschichte rund um die mutmaszliche Verschw√∂rung einer Gruppierung die letztenendes zum Attentat auf Franz Ferdinand f√ºhrte, welcher letztenendes zum 1. Weltkrieg f√ºhrt.

Das alles vermute ich weil ich es nicht zuende gespielt habe. (dazu gleich mehr)

Zu Allererst m√∂chte ich erw√§hnen dasz ich das "Spiel" an sich gut finde. Auch wenn die Interaktionsm√∂glichkeiten nahezu 0 vorhanden sind und man eigentlich nur klickt und liest, finde ich die Story sehr gut und die Musik stimmig. Grafik ist ausreichend. author: {'steamid': '76561198317143023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1883, 'last_played': 1642463746}
review:
This is a creatively presented experience, with much charm, innovation, and variety, but it is NOT really a game (... and it is not the famous Hitchcock movie-Alfred took MANY liberties). You follow the original 1914 novel--an old-fashioned but groundbreaking story about spies and conspiracies and evil foreigners, which captures something of the patriotism, nationalism and idealism of the period, for good and ill. 
Looking for mind-bending puzzles, or deep mysteries or impossibly difficult challenges? Forget it. There is also no obscenity or sex, no exciting jujitsu or preposterous gun fights, and very little violence... and yet there is suspense galore, a sense of threatening doom, and a satisfying conclusion. I loved it. 
If you're in a hurry, you are in the wrong place. My advice? Settle back in a good chair with an adult beverage, savor the author's voice, enjoy the story, follow the characters, and enter into the time--and just enjoy the ride. (On sale, this is an almighty good bargain.) Good triumphs over evil in the end!

author: {'steamid': '76561198141281551', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1495194340}

author: {'steamid': '76561198418549470', 'num_games_owned': 1152, 'num_reviews': 650, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1526770627}
review: Runs perfect on ubuntu linux. An emersive narriative experience. More than a visual novel, it is a way to jump into the story with sounds, art, and style. You have got to be in the mood for this type of thing, as this is a serious endeavor. There is a board game called Sherlock Holmes: Consulting Detective, that give you a map, newspaper, phone directory, to suppliment the story. That experience reminds me of this game. If you want to settle into a cup of tea and dig into photographs and newspapers from an England and Scotland of the 1910s, all of which are woven into an interesting narriative, then you will really enjoy this title. Otherwise (and more probably), you will find this terribly dull. I recommend this to people who are looking for an intellectual experience, but don't feel like picking up a book at this moment. On completing this visual novel, the list of credits rolled on for some time, and I knew that I would never grasp exactly how much effort went into creating this software. Between the hand painted scenes, the very excellent voice acting, the high-res photographs, great mouse-driven gestures, and the well placed chapter checkpoints, the story keeps delivering excellent game assets all the way to the finale. Bravo! Bravo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198114355236', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 391, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1515946764}
review:
When I first bought this game, I thought it was just a graphics novel adapted from the book. I was wrong, it is much more. It is a totally new take on an already marvelous book. In short, it is a pretty straighforward graphics novel mixing lots of different gameplay mechanics to give a somewhat interactive storytelling experience using rich, vibrant, and elaborate scenes that are true to that period in time. On top of that, a wonderful soundtrack and carefully placed sound effects bring the scene to life. IMO, it is not a perfect implementation of the idea and does have its fair share of flaws, but for a first take, it is very good.

On the plus (+) side:
[list]
    [*] Rich and vibrant scenes with enjoyable sound effects to match. Great attention to detail.
    [*] Scenes have a certain depth to them which can be seen when the camera moves as for example the background moves more than something in the foreground such as a window.
    [*] Collectibles exist that give more information on characters and none can be missed as they are automatically acquired by progressing in the story.
    [*] Scenes that should be voiced are voiced and narration, thoughts and actions are not voiced.
[/list]

On the negative (-) side:
[list]
    [*] Nothing much to interact with except mostly pieces of importance. No short wonder upon meaningless interaction with a seemingly background object, such as either a bird that flies away or a flag that flutters when the cursor is put over them.
    [*] I haven't read all the newspapers in detail, but important storywise, I have only seen one typing "error", or more accurately the word 'in' was repeated once right after it was used. (I was hesitating between putting this in + or -) 
    [*] Stopping to read the collectibles (or cards) is a must as soon as they are obtained as they give useful information to understand the characters as well as a photo of them (the characters are not shown during the story at all, only shadows).
    [*] Personally, I think that the narration should have been voiced. So, expect to read a lot and have a love to read to get through this.
    [*]  Again, personally, the real life photos broke immersion for me and I did not particularly like that, and if one thing should be changed, it's those. But then again, purely my opinion.
[/list]

NOTE (absolutely read before starting):
[olist]
    [*] The game introduces a clockwise and anti-clockwise rotation mechanics for progressing in the story, but left and right arrow of the keyboard works fine and is definitely less frustrating.
    [*] The menu can be quite confusing at first but it really is simple, have some patience. Also, do NOT right-click when it introduces the pause feature during the tutorial, it is frustrating especially as you might skip the tutorial. Feel free to experiment with right-click menu as soon as the tutorial ends and the first event (chapter) starts.
    [*] The Extras menu is confusing and is not just a statistics page. At first, I didn't realise that the options on the left side could be clicked on for further details as it does not look that way.
    [*] When an event ends and you are directly taken to the pause menu, just right-click to move on to the following event.
    [*] Easily put bookmarks (save games) by pressing 'A' at any time and in the bookmarks page, a very convenient % shows how much of the Event had been covered when it was created.
[/olist]

review:
Ce n'est pas vraiment un jeu, cela rentre plus dans l'histoire visuelle. Ici pas de gameplay, on branche son cerveau et on lit. Faut pas avoir peur de l'anglais!

M√™me si la musique du menu principal prend un peu la t√™te on appr√©cie √©normement les dessins style aquarelle.
Un tiers des passages se fait en audio avec sous-titres (merci pour l'accent du fond de la campagne √©cossaise) Certains passages (peu) mettront votre anglais √† l'√©preuve.

L'histoire en elle m√™me est un thriller qui se d√©roule en Angleterre et en Ecosse assez sympa.
Comptez une vingtaine de "chapitres" durant chacun 5 grosses minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112953754', 'num_games_owned': 1080, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1515353760}
review:
This game is an interesting way to consume a novel, though not for everyone. For some might appeal to boring, for others might be two childish, but for me it was just perfect.

It's a combination of a book, radio theater and adventure game. It looks that the team had put a lot of effort into this project, which is meticulously documented. All the details like the hand paintings to the newspaper cuts will throw you back in London 1914.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118075501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1515218759}
review: An excellent interactive kinetic novel of fictional pre-WWI espionage.  The protag becomes involved in preventing the success of a plot by a group of international conspirators to foment war for their financial and political gain.  This adaptation of the famous 1915 John Buchan book follows its story and pacing which differs from the Hitchcock movie with Robert Donat.  The game was a ‚Äúpage-turner‚Äù with good background art, excellent voice-acting, and appropriate BGM.  I wish this development team would bring more classic literature to the video game format.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.
